Section 401. - Zoning affects all land and buildings. No building, structure, or land shall be used or occupied, and no building, structure, or part thereof shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, enlarged, or structurally altered unless in conformity with the regulations of this ordinance. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 402. - Uses prohibited. If either a use, class of use, or structure for such use is not specifically indicated as being permitted in a district, either as a matter of right, or as a special use, then, such use, class of use, or structures for such uses, shall be prohibited in such district. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 403. - Location of building on zoning lots. Every building or structure erected or established in the City of Manchester shall be located on a zoning lot. In all cases, the principal building on a zoning lot shall be located within the buildable area formed by the building lines. In no case shall such buildings infringe beyond the building lines into the respective front, side or rear yards required for the district in which the zoning lot is located. Lanes associated with a drive-through window shall be considered part of the principal building when determining building location. In all residential zoning districts, there shall be no more than one principal building per lot. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 404. - Interpretation and application. In interpreting and applying these regulations, the requirements contained herein are declared to be the minimum requirement necessary to carry out the purpose of these regulations. Except as hereinafter provided, these regulations shall not be deemed to interfere with, abrogate, annul or otherwise affect in any manner whatsoever any easements, covenants, or other agreements between parties. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 405. - Street access. Except as otherwise provided herein, no building shall be erected, constructed, moved or relocated on a lot not located on a street that is permanently open to public use. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 406. - Access to property. Openings for vehicular access to zoning lots from public streets, commonly called curb cuts or driveways, shall be regulated in accordance with the following requirements: 406.1. Size and Spacing. In no case shall a curb cut or other access point be less than ten feet nor more than 30 feet in width. Except in residential zoning districts no two curb cuts or other access points shall be closer than 50 feet from each other. 406.2. Location. At street intersections, no curb cuts or other access points shall be located closer than 35 feet from the intersecting point of the street right-of-way lines. 406.3. Visibility. At any street intersection or at the intersection of any private driveway with a street, no fence, wall, sign, planting, or other structure or object shall be permitted or maintained that will form an impediment to visibility within 35 feet of the point of intersection of the driving surfaces (or such lines extended in the case of rounded corners). 406.4. Permit Required. No person shall be authorized to open any curb cut, grade or otherwise make any improvements upon the public right-of-way of any street, road or highway, except under permit issued by the building official; such permit shall be issued only upon condition that the applicant agree to indemnify and hold the city harmless for any injury or damage to public utilities and improvements existing within said right-of-way over which any driveway or other improvement is to be built, and upon condition that the city may require the property owner, at his sole expense, to remove any permitted improvement, or to relocate or repair the same, as necessary for the maintenance and future improvement of said right-of-way, including the location, relocation, repair or removal of utilities existing therein. Application for the permit shall be made on forms provided by the building official. A permit fee, as provided in appendix "A" shall be paid at time of application. 406.5. New Subdivisions or Developments Fronting Upon the State Highway System. Whenever a new subdivision or development is proposed, which fronts upon the state highway system, and requires access therefrom, no final approval of subdivision or development plans shall be given by the city, unless the developer has submitted the final plat to the department of transportation, pursuant to the requirement of O.C.G.A. § 32-6-151, and received the approval thereof. The time limitations for final approval of a subdivision or development plan under this ordinance and the development ordinance (Appendix B) shall not be deemed to begin until such approval has been granted. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 407. - Amendment of zoning ordinance and map; review standards; application procedures. 407.1. All amendments to this ordinance, either to the text or map, shall be accomplished in accordance with this chapter. 407.2. All amendments to this ordinance shall be consistent with the future land use component for the City of Manchester, as contained in the joint comprehensive plan of Meriwether County, Georgia, 1994, as amended, unless significant justification exists based upon an analysis of the standards set forth in section 407.3. The applicant shall bear the burden of proof and persuasion. 407.3. All proposed amendments to the zoning map shall be considered in light of the following six standards used to interpret the balance between an individual's right to the unfettered use of his or her property and the public health, safety, morality, or general welfare of the community. In applying these standards, expression of public opinion unsupported by objective facts shall not be given weight by the mayor and council: A. Whether the property to be affected by the zoning proposal has a reasonable economic use as currently zoned, although such use may not be its highest and best potential use. B. Whether the zoning proposal will permit a use that is suitable in view of the use and development of adjacent and nearby property. C. If not suitable, whether the zoning proposal can be conditioned so that it will not adversely affect the existing use of adjacent or nearby property. D. Whether the zoning proposal will result in a use which will or could cause an excessive or burdensome use of existing streets, transportation facilities, utilities, or schools. E. Whether there are other existing or changing conditions which give supporting grounds for either approval or disapproval of the zoning proposal. F. If applicable, the length of time the property has remained vacant as zoned, considered in the context of land development in the vicinity of the property. 407.4. Amendments may be proposed by the zoning administrator, the mayor and council, PZB, any owner of property within the City of Manchester, or the owner's legal representative. 407.5. All applications for amendment shall be made in writing, on forms provided by the zoning administrator, and filed with the zoning administrator. 407.6. No application will be considered to have been accepted until such forms as described in section 407.5 have been completed and submitted to the zoning administrator for filing, with the proscribed fees. 407.7. Application forms shall include any request for information deemed necessary by the zoning administrator and may include: drawings showing the dimensions of existing and proposed buildings; entrances and exits from the property described in the application; a detailed description of existing land uses on adjacent and surrounding property; the location of the subject property, including street number, if any; a plat of the land in question, or a description by metes and bounds, bearings and distances of the land, or if the boundaries conform to the lot boundaries within a subdivision for which a plat is recorded in the land records of Meriwether County, then, the lot, block and subdivision designations with appropriate plat reference; the present and proposed zoning district classification for the subject property; the name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s) of the subject property; the area of land proposed to be rezoned, stated in square feet if less than one acre and in acres of one or more; and the application number, date of application and action taken on all prior applications filed for rezoning of all or part of the subject property. 407.8. Any communication relative to an application for amendment will be regarded as informational only until a proper and complete application for amendment is made. 407.9. Upon receipt of application for amendment, the zoning administrator shall send a copy of the application to each member of the mayor and council and of the planning and zoning board. The individual officials shall file such conflict of interest disclosures as may be required by O.C.G.A. title 36, chapter 67A. (See appendix C.) 407.10. The PZB may, but is not required to, hold a public hearing on the proposed amendment, and shall submit its recommendations to the mayor and council within 45 days of receipt of the proposed amendment from the zoning administrator. If a public hearing is to be held, notice thereof shall be published in The Meriwether Vindicator at least 15 days prior thereto. 407.11. Within 45 days of receipt by the mayor and council of the recommendation from the PZB on an application for amendment, the mayor and council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed amendment under the procedures in section 408. 407.12. The mayor and council, in its legislative discretion, shall approve or deny the proposed amendment as submitted or conditioned, defer a decision until a specific meeting date, require the applicant to file additional information or plans regarding the project development and defer action to a later meeting date, or allow a withdrawal by the applicant if requested. Voluntary withdrawal shall not constitute a denial for purposes of section 407.19. In approving an ordinance, the mayor and council may require that zoning conditions be added or deleted, as recommended by the zoning administrator and PZB, or upon its own initiative. The vote of each member of the mayor and council shall be recorded in the official minutes. Any tie vote shall constitute a denial of the proposed amendment. 407.13. The mayor and council, zoning administrator, and PZB may defer action or recommendation for a reasonable length of time on any application for amendment pending submission of additional information, as requested of the applicant. Any delay must be explained to the applicant. 407.14. After final action by the mayor and council on a proposed ordinance, any necessary changes to the official map shall be made within 30 days and shall indicate the effective date of the amendment. 407.15. A temporary notation or a temporary map showing the necessary zoning map change(s) described in section 407.12 shall indicate the effective date of the amendment. 407.16. An approved amendment to the zoning map(s) becomes effective upon posting of a temporary notation or a temporary map showing the necessary zoning map change(s). 407.17. The city clerk shall convey a written decision on proposed amendments to the person or persons proposing such amendment within seven days of making such decision. 407.18. All records concerning proposed amendments to this ordinance, including those approved, denied, or deferred for more information, shall be kept by the zoning administrator. 407.19. If the application for amendment is ultimately denied by the mayor and council the same amendment shall not be reconsidered for at least six months from the date of such denial. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 408. - Public information. This section includes requirements for public hearings, meetings, notice, and access to records. All hearings, meetings, notice, and records relative to this zoning ordinance shall follow the procedures established in this section. 408.1. Hearings. 1. The Mayor or presiding Council Member shall indicate that a public hearing has been called for the consideration of zoning decisions. Thereupon the Council shall consider each application on an individual basis. 2. A minimum of ten minutes per side shall be afforded for presentation of data, evidence, and opinion by proponents and opponents of each zoning decision, and a five-minute rebuttal time limit for the applicant. The Council may, but shall not be obligated to, ask for a show of hands for those persons who appear in support of/opposition to the petition. If it appears that the number of persons wishing to appear in support of/opposition to the petition is in excess of that which may reasonably be heard, the Council may request that a spokesperson for the group be chosen so that the entire presentation of the positions of those in support of/opposition to the petition shall not exceed 30 minutes. 3. In the absence of the applicant at a rezoning public hearing, after hearing from those present, the public hearing may be continued to another date for further information. 4. While everyone has the right to disagree, members of the audience that are continually disruptive to and disrespectful of the purpose of the meeting, participants in the meeting, and each other are politely and respectfully urged to refrain from their actions or shall vacate the meeting. 5. After the public hearing is closed, the Council may immediately thereafter vote upon the proposed change or it may delay the vote to a subsequent meeting. ** Zoning issues are further subject to the City of Manchester Zoning Ordinance. 408.2. Meetings. A. All meetings, both regular and special, at which an application filed pursuant to this ordinance is to be discussed, considered, or acted upon by the mayor and council, shall be open to the public. Notice of special meetings shall be given in accordance with the Georgia Open Meetings Law. B. Where proper notice is given, by publication, in accordance with this ordinance, and in conformity with the Georgia Open Meetings Law, and, when required, a sign has been posted in accordance with this ordinance, no further notice to the property owner or any adjacent or nearby property owners is required. Failure to provide notice as required by this ordinance may constitute grounds for the final action on an application to be declared null and void. It is the responsibility of the applicant to satisfy himself prior to the public hearing that proper notice requirements have been met and evidenced in the record of the hearing. Appearance at the public hearing shall constitute a waiver of all claims based upon improper publication of notice or posting on the property. 408.3. Records and Minutes of Proceedings. Copies of applications, proposed ordinances, supporting documents and plats, written evaluations and recommendations by the zoning administrator and PZB, and minutes of all related proceedings shall be deemed a part of the official record. When the mayor and council conducts a public hearing on the adoption of a zoning ordinance, the amendment to the text of this ordinance, or an amendment to the classification of property as shown on the official zoning map, the mayor and council is deemed to act in a legislative capacity, and written minutes shall be taken which fairly and accurately reflect the proceedings. When acting in a quasi-judicial capacity to apply this ordinance in consideration of an application for variance, or special use written minutes shall be prepared which fairly and accurately summarize the testimony of any witness presented and which attach any documentary evidence presented at the hearing. Any person interested in a hearing shall have the right, at their own expense, to have a verbatim transcript prepared by a court reporter. 408.4. Rezoning Signs. A. The applicant for rezoning shall leave with the zoning administrator, upon submission of application forms, a deposit for the above-mentioned signs, in an amount set by the mayor and council. Such deposit shall be returned to the applicant upon return of the signs to the zoning administrator in good condition. B. The applicant shall remove any and all rezoning signs from the subject property within three business days after the date of hearing on the proposed rezoning. (Ord. of 1-9-2015; Ord. of 1-12-2015) Section 409. - Appeals. 409.1. Appellate Procedure. Persons aggrieved by any decision of the mayor and council arising from a legislative action by the mayor and council may seek declaratory relief and/or equitable relief from the superior court of Meriwether County. Persons aggrieved by any quasi-judicial action may petition the superior court for issuance of a writ of certiorari. All appellate proceedings must be filed within 30 days of the date the mayor and council take final action on the matter, regardless of the action's effective date. 409.2. Extent of Authority of the Mayor and Council. The mayor and council may not, in conformity with the provisions of this ordinance, reverse or modify, wholly or in part, any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the zoning administrator resulting in the denial of a development or construction permit where a ground for denial is that the existing zoning does not allow such proposed structure or use, or that a specific variance, special use, or continuation or enlargement of a nonconforming use is first required. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 410. - Special uses; criteria for granting. The mayor and council shall hear and decide upon special uses. No permit shall be granted in an individual case unless a written application for a special use is submitted by the applicant indicating the section of this ordinance under which the special use is sought. All applications shall be reviewed by the PZB for recommendation. Before any special use shall be issued, the mayor and council shall consider whether satisfactory provisions and arrangement have been made concerning the following, where applicable: 410.1. Ingress and egress to property and proposed structures thereon with particular reference to automotive and pedestrian safety and convenience, traffic flow and control, and access in case of fire or catastrophe. 410.2. Off-street parking and loading areas where required, with particular attention to the items in section 410.1 above and the economic, noise, glare, or odor effects of the special use on adjoining properties and properties generally in the area. Days and hours of operation may be specified as a condition for granting the special use. 410.3. Uses involving public assemblies, such as churches, auditoriums, theatres, meeting halls, restaurants, and similar places where crowds are likely to congregate shall meet all applicable fire, life safety, sanitation and health codes, and accessibility codes for persons with disabilities. 410.4. Utilities, with reference to location, availability, and compatibility. Refuse and service areas, with particular reference to the items in sections 410.1 and 410.2 above. 410.5. Screening and buffering with reference to type, dimension, and character. 410.6. Signs, if any, and proposed exterior lighting with reference to glare, traffic safety, economic effect, and compatibility and harmony with properties in the district and with the provisions of the Manchester Sign Ordinance as set forth in chapter 58 of Part II, Code of Ordinances. 410.7. Adequacy of required minimum yards and other open space; provided, greater buffer requirements can be imposed as a condition for granting the special use. 410.8. General compatibility of the proposed special use with adjacent properties and other land uses in the general area. 410.9. The proposed use will not constitute a nuisance or hazard or otherwise adversely affect the public interest because of: A. The number of persons who attend or use such facility; B. Noise or fumes generated; or C. Type of physical activity. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 411. - Variances. The mayor and council, upon recommendation of the PZB, may authorize, in specific cases, such variance from the terms of this ordinance as will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special circumstances, literal enforcement of the provisions of this ordinance will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship, so that the spirit of these regulations shall be observed, public safety and welfare secured, and substantial justice done; provided, however, that a variance shall not be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited by this ordinance in the district in question. The variance granted shall be the minimum variance that will make possible the reasonable use of the land, building and/or structure. No variance shall be granted in an individual case unless and until a written application for a variance is submitted by the applicant demonstrating: 411.1. There are extraordinary, exceptional or peculiar conditions and circumstances pertaining to the particular piece of land, structure or building in question which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 411.2. The application of these regulations to a particular piece of property would create a practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship; 411.3. Relief, if granted, would not be injurious to the neighborhood or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare or impair the purposes and intent of these regulations; 411.4. A literal interpretation of this ordinance would deprive the applicant of any rights that others in the same district are entitled to enjoy; 411.5. That the special conditions and circumstances alleged are not the result of any contrived actions of the applicant; and 411.6. That granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this ordinance to other lands, structures, or buildings similarly situated. In exercising the above powers, the mayor and council shall not consider any nonconforming use of neighboring lands, structures or buildings in the same or any other district, and no permitted use of lands, structures or buildings in other districts as grounds for the issuance of a variance. Under no circumstances shall the mayor and council grant a variance to allow a use not permissible under the terms of this ordinance in the district involved or any use expressly or by implication prohibited by the terms of this ordinance in said district. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 412. - Preapplication conference. Upon request for application for rezoning, special use, variance, or continuation or enlargement of a nonconforming use, the applicant is encouraged to meet with the zoning administrator to discuss the pertinent regulations relative to the request made. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 413. - Payment of taxes; acknowledgement forms. Applications required by this ordinance shall be made on forms provided by the zoning administrator, and all information required on said forms shall be provided by the appellant. No form shall be accepted by the zoning administrator unless it contains all pertinent information and is accompanied by the required fee, as set from time to time by the city council. All applications shall be accompanied by a statement from the tax commissioner of Meriwether County and the treasurer of the city that all ad valorem taxes levied against the subject property, and due and owing, have been paid. Included in all applications shall be a form whereby the applicant acknowledges that he/she has had the opportunity to participate in a preapplication conference with the zoning administrator and has had the opportunity to read and/or purchase a copy of this ordinance. (See appendix B for acknowledgment form.) (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 414. - Rules of procedure. The zoning administrator shall have the authority to adopt rules of procedure in implementation of this ordinance. Such rules shall be in writing and shall be approved by the mayor and council. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 415. - Other duties. The zoning administrator shall have the authority to take on additional duties, not inconsistent with the intent of this ordinance or with other ordinances or regulations relative to planning and development in the City of Manchester. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 416. - Reserved. Section 417. - Annexation; dispute resolution procedures. It is the intent of the mayor and council that no land within the City of Manchester shall be unzoned. Statutory procedures are available whereby the mayor and council is authorized to adopt ordinances amending the geographic boundaries of the city. Annexation may also be achieved through local act of the general assembly. Simultaneous with adoption of an annexation ordinance, the city must initially zone the property annexed. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 418. - Nonconforming uses. Any lawfully existing building, structure or use of land which is not a permitted use in the district within which it is located upon enactment of this ordinance into law or upon subsequent amendment of this ordinance, shall be deemed to be a lawfully existing nonconforming use. This definition shall not be construed to include among lawfully existing nonconforming uses those buildings, structures or uses which prior to the enactment of this ordinance were not lawfully existing in accordance with all applicable codes, ordinances, and regulations. Any lawfully existing nonconforming use may be continued subject to the following conditions: 418.1. Change. Once changed to a conforming use no building, structure, or use of land shall be permitted to revert to a nonconforming use. Change of a nonconforming use to another nonconforming use is prohibited. 418.2. Discontinuance. Reestablishing a nonconforming use after discontinuance for a period of 12 months shall be prohibited unless otherwise granted by the mayor and council as set forth in Section 408. 418.3. Restoration. A nonconforming building or structure shall not be restored or structurally altered for continuance as a nonconforming use if the cost of such restoration or alteration exceeds 50 percent of its replacement cost, less depreciation. Any permitted restoration or alteration of a nonconforming building or structure shall be fully completed within a twelve-month period after issuance of the building permit for each restoration or alteration. 418.4. Extension. A nonconforming building, structure or use shall not be enlarged or extended in such a way as to displace a conforming use unless otherwise granted by the mayor and council as set forth in Section 408. Further, no nonconforming building, structure or use may be extended to occupy additional land area not utilized for such nonconforming building, structure, or use as of the date of enactment of this ordinance. 418.5. Unlawful Nonconforming Uses. Notwithstanding any other provision of this ordinance, any existing nonconforming use which was illegal under any prior zoning ordinance shall remain illegal hereunder and subject to all penalties and remedies provided hereunder as well as to all penalties and remedies previously provided unless said use is permitted by the zoning map adopted herein. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 419. - Home occupations. A home occupation is any trade, business or occupation customarily engaged in for gain or profit if conducted on residential premises by a person or family residing therein. A home occupation as defined by this ordinance shall be governed by the following requirements: 419.1. At least one full-time resident of the dwelling shall be engaged in the home occupation. 419.2. The home occupation shall be clearly incidental to the residential use of the dwelling and shall not change the essential residential character of the building. 419.3. No display of products shall be visible from the street, and only products produced in the premises may be sold on the premises, except that bona fide agricultural products grown on the premises may be displayed in an A/R district. 419.4. Only one point of business identification sign, not exceeding two square feet in size, motionless, nonlighted, and attached to the principal building, shall be permitted. 419.5. No internal or external alterations inconsistent with the residential use of the building shall be permitted. 419.6. The occupation shall not constitute a nuisance in the neighborhood. 419.7. No accessory buildings or outside storage shall be used in connection with the occupation except as otherwise provided in this ordinance. 419.8. Vehicles used primarily as passenger vehicles only shall be permitted in connection with the conduct of the customary home occupation. 419.9. In addition to the parking otherwise required by this ordinance, off-street parking shall be provided for each employee of the home occupation and at least two spaces for customers or clients; provided, however, total off-street parking shall not exceed five spaces unless special use is granted by the mayor and council. 419.10. The following and similar uses shall customarily be considered home occupations: addressing service, artist or art instructor, beauty shop (with no more than one operator), dentist, attorney, doctor, drafting, dressmaking, insurance agent, manufacturing agent, music teacher, notary public, photographer, real estate agent, tax consultant, tourist home, bed and breakfast home, day care for no more than four nonrelated children; licensed family day care home, provided such home is located in a single-family residence on a lot having at least 5,445 square feet of gross lot area. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 420. - Street classification. The classification of each road and street as defined in section 202.69 and the comprehensive plan, 1994, as amended, may be revised, from time to time, by resolution of the mayor and council. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 421. - Zoning to apply when lot is divided by district boundary line. In the event that a district boundary line on the zoning map divides a lot of record held in one ownership on the date of passage of this ordinance, the entire lot shall be used in conformity with the regulations established by this ordinance for the district in which 50 percent or more of such parcel is located; provided, however, that if the property owner of such a lot so desires, he may apply to the city for subdivision of the lot into two or more lots of record within the respective zones. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 422. - Easements. No permanent structures or improvement shall be placed within any easement area. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 423. - Substandard lots of record. Any lot of record existing at the time of the adoption of this ordinance, which has an area or other dimension which is less than required by this ordinance, shall be subject to the following exceptions and modifications: 423.1. Adjoining Lots. When two or more adjoining lots with continuous frontage are in one ownership at any time after adoption of this ordinance and such lots individually are less than the minimum square footage and/or have less than the minimum width required in the district in which they are located, then, such group of lots shall be considered as a single lot or several lots of minimum permitted width and area for the district in which located; provided, however, that when such combination of lots would create a single lot having a width and area 1¾ times or more than that width and area required by this ordinance, then, such lot may be divided into two lots of equal width and equal area and said lots used as conforming lots. 423.2. Lot Not Meeting Minimum Lot Size Requirements. Except as set forth in section 423.1 above, in any district, any lot of record existing at the time of the adoption of this ordinance which has an area or a width which is less than that required by this ordinance may be used as a building site for a structure or other use permitted in that zone; provided, however, that the same yard, setback, open space, and other dimensional requirements are met that would be required for a standard lot of required size in that zoning district. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 424. - Open space not to be encroached upon. No open space shall be encroached upon or reduced in any manner except in conformity to the yard, setback, off-street parking spaces, and such other regulations required by this ordinance for the district in which such building is located. (See sections 425, 426, and 427.) Shrubbery, driveways, retaining walls, fences, curbs, and planted buffer strips shall be construed not to be encroachments of open spaces. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 425. - Permitted modification of setback requirements. When a building is proposed on a lot and when on either or both lots which adjoin such lot at the street right-of-way line there exists a principal building which does not conform to the setback requirements of this ordinance, required setback for such building shall be as follows: (1) Where only one said adjoining lot contains a principal building with a nonconforming setback, the setback shall be the computed average of (a) the normal setback requirements with (b) the nonconforming setback; or (2) Where both adjoining lots contain a principal building each with a nonconforming setback, the minimum setback shall be the computed average of the two nonconforming setbacks. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 426. - Modification of side yard requirements. Except where zero-lot-line dwellings have been approved, whenever the mayor and council considers an application for variance to reduce the side yard requirements for a residential lot, the side yard may not be reduced to less than one-half the stated minimum. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 427. - Permitted encroachments of yards and setbacks. Architectural features such as cornices, eaves, steps, gutters, and fire escapes may project not more than three feet beyond any required setback line, except where such projections would obstruct driveways which are, or may be used for access for service and/or emergency vehicles; provided, however, that in the case of automobile service stations, motels, and similar uses which serve the motoring public, canopies shall be allowed over a driveway or walkway within the front yard not to extend from the principal building to a point any closer than 15 feet from the street right-of-way line. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 428. - Required open space may not be used by another building. No part of any yard or open space, or off-street parking or loading space required in connection with any building, structure, or use by this ordinance shall be considered to be part of a required yard, or other open space, or off-street parking or loading space for any other building, structure or use. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 429. - Structures permitted above the height limit. The height limits of these regulations shall not apply to church spires, belfries, silos, cupolas, domes, ornamental towers, monuments, water towers, observation towers, transmission towers, chimneys, smokestacks, conveyor, flag pole, radio or television tower, mast or aerial, parapet wall not extending more than four feet above the roof line of the building, necessary mechanical appurtenances, and other such structures not intended for human occupancy; provided, such structure or portion of such structure will not interfere with any established airport approach zones, flight patterns, or solar access. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 430. - Reduction of yards or lot area. No lot existing at the time of passage of this ordinance, January 9, 2015, shall be reduced, divided, or changed so as to produce a tract of land which does not comply with the minimum dimension or area requirements of this ordinance for the district in which it is located unless said reduction or division is necessary to provide land that is needed and accepted for public use. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 431. - Encroachment on public rights-of-way. No building, structure, service area, or required off-street parking and/or loading facilities, except driveways, shall be permitted to encroach upon public rights-of-way. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 432. - Location of accessory building or uses. Accessory buildings on lots, when located within a front or side yard, shall be located no closer to property lines than would be allowed for a principal building. Within a rear yard, an accessory building on a residential lot shall be located at least five feet from all rear property lines and eight feet from all other property lines, except that in the case of corner lots, accessory buildings shall be set back from the centerline of an abutting street right-of-way a distance equal to the front yard setback established for the zoning district in which the accessory buildings are located. In the case of a double-frontage lot (see sections 201.46 and 435), accessory buildings shall conform to front yard setbacks on both streets. Swimming pools accessory to residences shall be enclosed by a fence of minimum height of four feet. Accessory buildings or uses on nonresidential lots shall comply with front, side and rear yard requirements established for the zoning district in which such accessory buildings or uses are located. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 433. - Corner lots. On lots having frontage on more than one street at an intersection, the minimum front yard setback for the district shall apply along both street frontages, and one of the other lot sides must conform to the minimum rear yard setback. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 434. - Double-frontage lots. On lots having frontage on more than one street, not at an intersection, the minimum front yard setback for the district shall apply along both street frontages. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 435. - Lots with multiple frontage. In the case of a corner lot, side yard setback requirements from the centerline of the street right-of-way shall be equal to 75 percent of that required for the front yard setback for the district. On a corner lot where the main entrance into a residence is facing a side yard, it shall be permissible for purposes of this ordinance to construe the residence to be fronting on the street other than that street which said entrance faces, and side and rear yard requirements having frontage on two roads not at an intersection, a setback from each road shall be provided equal to the front yard requirement for the district in which the lot is located. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 436. - Visibility at intersections. On corner lots within all zoning districts, no fence, shrubbery or other obstructions to the traffic sight visions, except utility poles or traffic light or sign standards, shall be erected within a triangular area formed by the intersection of the right-of-way lines of two streets or a street intersection with a railroad right-of-way line, and a diagonal line which intersects the right-of-way lines at two points, each 20 feet distance from the intersection of the right-of-way lines, or, in the case of a rounded corner, from the point of intersection of their tangents. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 437. - Side and rear yards not required next to railroad. Within any nonresidential district, side yards and rear yards shall not be required adjacent to railroad rights-of-way. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 438. - Fences and walls. No fence or freestanding wall, other than a required retaining wall, shall be erected in a residential zoning district between the public right-of-way and the front setback line, established by this ordinance or the building line as shown on an approved subdivision plan, whichever is greater; otherwise, no fence or freestanding wall, other than a retaining wall, in a required setback area for a residential zoning district, shall be more than six feet in height above finished grade, except as for required screening. (See section 441.) (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 439. - Required buffers in commercial and industrial districts. In any commercial or industrial zoning district where a lot abuts any residential district, a 25-foot-wide buffer shall be provided with screening as specified in section 441. Off-street parking associated with such uses shall be governed by this same provision. In applicable situations, this section controls over the setback requirements of section 505. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 440. - Screening of service areas within 100 feet of public street. Any service area, loading area, refuse, or storage area between a principal building and a public street being visible from said street and lying within 100 feet of said street shall be provided with screening as specified in section 441, if within any commercial or manufacturing district. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 441. - Screening required. Whenever screening is required by this ordinance, a durable masonry wall, or fence and hedge of sufficient opacity to provide a visual blind designed to be compatible with the character of adjoining properties, shall be provided. Such fences and/or walls shall be at least six feet in height, but no greater than eight feet in height, measured from the ground along the common lot lines of the adjoining properties. When hedges or natural plantings are used, (together with the fence prescribed), to form the required screening, the minimum sufficient opacity shall be deemed to require no less than three feet of plantings and/or hedge in the area immediately adjacent to the fence, measured along the ground surface from the fence to the inside border of said plantings and/or hedge plantings. Hedges of comparable natural plantings shall be of such variety that an average height of at least six feet could be expected by normal growth within no later than two years from the time of planting. At the time of the application for a building permit, the applicant shall post a performance bond in the amount sufficient to cover the cost of installation of the required screening. If, at the end of the two-year period, the buffered screening is satisfactorily in place as prescribed in this section, the amount of the bond shall be returned to the applicant; however, if the required screening is not completed satisfactorily as set forth in this section by the end of the two-year period, the bond shall be deemed forfeited and the required screening will be installed by the City of Manchester, using the funds from the proceeds of the cash bond posted by the applicant. At the time of the application for a building permit the applicant shall execute a license to the City of Manchester on and over the land site for which application has been made, sufficient to allow the City of Manchester to enter onto the property and perform the required screening work. The zoning administrator shall make determination of the degree of satisfactory completion of required screening according to a common standard; the zoning administrator's decisions in each instance may be appealed to the mayor and council. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 442. - Fallout shelters. Fallout shelters are permitted as principal or accessory uses in any districts, subject to the yard requirements of the district. Shelters shall be maintained so as not to become a hazard or blight to the community. The mayor and council may permit as a special exception, construction of joint shelters by two or more property owners. When such shelters are permitted, the mayor and city council may waive the side and rear requirements on the property or properties directly involved in order to permit practical and efficient location and construction; provided, however, that side yard requirements shall be met where property involved, in a joint proposal, abuts or adjoins property not included in the proposal. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 443. - Temporary uses. The zoning administrator is authorized to issue a temporary certificate of occupancy for temporary uses, subject to the applicable conditions for each temporary use and provided that it is clearly determined such uses are of a temporary nature, will cause no traffic congestion, and will not adversely affect surrounding uses. 443.1. Play tents shall be permitted in all residential zoning districts as a temporary accessory use for a period not to exceed seven days. Family camping tents are allowed only in designated camping areas within the city for periods not to exceed 15 consecutive days. Any commercial tent, having an area of 150 square feet or more, requires a temporary use permit to be issued by the zoning administrator, which shall be good for not more than 30 days from date of issuance; provided, adequate parking is available for the intended temporary activity. Any sign used in conjunction with a commercial tent must be approved by the zoning administrator. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 444. - Access for persons with disabilities. All multifamily buildings consisting of four or more units if such buildings have one or more elevators, all ground floor units in all other multifamily buildings consisting of two or more units, all single-family dwellings and all institutional, commercial and industrial buildings intended for use by the general public shall be designed and constructed so that the public use and common use portions of such structures are readily accessible to and usable by persons with disabilities. All doors shall be designed to allow passage by disabled persons in wheelchairs, and all structures shall contain the following features of adaptive design: (i) An accessible route into and through the structure; (ii) Light switches, electrical outlets, thermostats, and other environmental controls in accessible locations; (iii) Reinforcements in bathroom walls to allow later installation of grab bars; and (iv) Usable kitchens and bathrooms such that an individual in a wheelchair can maneuver about the space. Compliance with the appropriate requirements of ANSI A117.1 shall suffice to satisfy the requirements of this section. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 445. - Manufactured and industrialized buildings. Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed to discriminate against manufactured or industrialized buildings. All residential structures erected or located within the City of Manchester shall be constructed, and erected or installed on a permanent foundation, have a pitched roof of at least 3:12 slope, be covered with either fiberglass or asphalt composition shingles, or an approved wooden roofing shingle or shake or approved corrugated steel roofing, and be no more than ten years old. No smooth sheet aluminum, ribbed fiberglass, or light gauge corrugated metal shall be used for residential roofing. Exterior siding shall be used for residential in appearance, such as wood, clapboards, or vinyl siding, and as compatible as possible with any existing residential structures in the neighborhood. Where a manufactured or industrialized building (residential, commercial or industrial) is to be installed, the unit must bear the insignia of the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Georgia Department of Community Affairs, or the Southern Building Code Congress International. All such structures shall be affixed to the foundation in accordance with minimum standards of the certifying agency, with hitch, axles and wheels removed. Where porches, decks, carports, garages and other attachments are made to a manufactured building, such attachments shall conform to the pertinent statewide minimum construction code and shall, to the extent possible, continue the existing roofline and slope. All manufactured and industrialized buildings shall be returned for al valorem tax purposes as real property. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 446. - New building and housing technologies. Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed as to discriminate against solar, earth-sheltered, or other emerging building and housing technologies. No minimum height requirements for buildings or houses shall be established. Completely below grade, earth-covered spaces shall not be included in maximum lot coverage calculations since the concerns of water runoff and creating adequate open space around buildings are alleviated. Earth-sheltered designs in which the roof grade is somewhat higher than the surrounding grade may not create the desired open space and building mass relationships intended by the regulations and thus may not be exempt from the lot coverage requirements of this ordinance. No provisions are made in this ordinance which require that a building or house be oriented in a particular direction. Property owners shall be allowed to construct a building or house on their property (subject to the provisions of this ordinance), with regard to solar orientation regardless of direction from building or house to the street. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 447. - Civil penalties. Every violation of the terms of this ordinance by any person, firm or corporation shall be deemed a nuisance, and a continuing nuisance for each day such violation may be continued and such violation may be subject to abatement as a nuisance as provided by the laws of this state and ordinances of the city. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 448. - Criminal penalties. Any firm, person or corporation who shall intentionally do anything prohibited by this ordinance as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended, or who shall fail to do anything required by this ordinance as it now exists or as it may hereafter be amended, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. Each and every day that such violation exists shall be deemed a separate offense. The owner of any building or premises or part thereof where anything in violation of this ordinance shall be placed or shall exist and any architect, builder, contractor or agent of the owner who may have assisted in the commission of such violation shall be tried, upon citation, before the municipal court. Upon conviction, the person or persons shall be fined not more than $1,000.00 for each offense. The guilty party shall pay all costs as determined by the court. Each day's continuance of a violation shall be considered a separate offense. Citations may be issued by the city manager, zoning administrator, city police officer, building official, or other code enforcement officer. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 449. - Apartments in commercial buildings in c-1 and c-2 zoning classifications. A. Purpose. The purpose of allowing residential apartments in commercial buildings on a limited and select basis in certain zoning districts is to encourage residential uses within these districts to accommodate residents who need easy and direct access to their place of work, to create an alternative housing option, to facilitate a housing option that is compatible with street level commercial uses with a minimum of disruption to those uses, and to provide an added security measure by creating a district that is active 24 hours a day. B. Districts Permitted. Residential apartments in commercial buildings are permitted as a Special Use in the following zoning districts: C-1 and C-2 only. 1. Infrastructure Requirements. Residential apartments above storefronts must meet the following infrastructure requirements: A. Water and Sewer Requirements: Public water and sewer shall be required. B. Sidewalk Requirements: Sidewalks adjacent to the building containing such units shall be required. C. Additional Development Requirements. A. If residential uses are provided above the street level, such uses shall have separate and distinct entrances. Windows of at least 30 inches × 36 inches shall be provided at a minimum of one per unit. All street facades shall provide windows of at least 30 inches × 42 inches no more than eight feet apart, provide such windows in consistent heights and separations, and be clear and unobstructed by signs or other non-residential coverings. In addition, such residences, must meet the following requirements: 1. Units may be permitted as a Special Use on the street level, basement or upper levels of the building. Units must be a minimum of 850 square feet. Street based units must be in the rear of the building, shall not be visible from the front of the street and the entry to the unit shall be from the back of the building. No street level units will be allowed unless the building contains a minimum of 2550.00 square feet on the street level. 2. Building Codes. All such residential units shall comply with all existing commercial building codes and fire codes (NFPA Life Safety Code, 1991 Edition; Southern Building Code Standard Fire prevention Code) with fire walls. 3. Restrictions. a. All windows treatments shall be off-white colors with no signs, drawings, or photographs incorporated therein. Nothing shall hang from the outside of the windows. b. No outside mailboxes shall be permitted; inside mailboxes or mail slots shall be used. c. No outside radio or television antennas or satellite reception dishes shall be permitted; cable connections shall be permitted and located at the rear of the building. d. No daily or weekly boarding rooms shall be permitted. Only complete dwelling units as defined herein may be established. e. Each dwelling unit shall be furnished with a washer and dryer or be located no more than 500 feet from a common wash area accessible to residents or a public Laundromat; each unit must contain a garbage disposal unit. f. Outside building identification numbers shall be provided and not exceed six inches in height. g. No drying of clothes shall be permitted on the outside of any building. h. Entry to the unit or to a hallway serving one or more units shall be provided by a stairway opening directly to the outside at street level. All entry stairways shall be enclosed and secured. For buildings with multiple units, a central common hallway conveniently serving all units shall be established. i. All window air-conditioning units shall not be visible from any public street. j. No outdoor cooking shall be permitted. k. No maintenance, washing, or detailing of vehicles is permitted. l. No recreation, entertainment public gathering, or placement of furniture shall be allowed on the sidewalks adjacent to the building containing the units unless permitted by City Council. m. No garage, yard, estate, rummage or other similar sales shall be permitted. 5. Landlords shall furnish a City approved trash container and recycling bin for each dwelling unit that shall be located with the approval of the City. A copy of these requirements shall be made a part of each lease agreement. a. Residential areas shall be designed in such a manner as to provide a safe and secure environment for residence. This shall include, at a minimum, secured common building entrances to residential areas which, for entrances serving six or more units, shall open to a heated lobby of a minimum of ten square feet per unit up to 300 square feet. b. Common residential building entrances shall be physically separated and distinct form commercial or other non-residential building entrances. Entrances for units on street levels must be in the rear of the building. c. For buildings with multiple apartment units, a central hallway conveniently serving all units shall be established. d. All construction of apartments above commercial storefronts shall comply with all building codes governing residential development. D. Unit Registration and Permitting. A. Registration. Each apartment approval as a special exception must be with the City Clerk and the owner shall keep all information related to the unit current. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) ARTICLE 5. - ESTABLISHMENT OF ZONING DISTRICTS
Section 501. - Districts enumerated. For the purpose of this ordinance, the City of Manchester, Georgia, is divided into the following zoning districts:
(Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 502. - Definitions of zoning districts. A. R-E Estate Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having a very-low-density, single-family character on lots of approximately one acre and additional open area where it is desirable and likely that similar development will occur. The most stringent development requirements and restrictions in this zoning district will serve to guarantee that the area's natural beauty will not be abused as well as encourage similar development. B. R-1 Low-Density Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having a low-density, single-family residential character and additional open area where it is desirable and likely that similar development will occur. Stricter development requirements and restrictions in this zoning district will serve to guarantee that the area's natural beauty will not be abused as well as encourage similar development. C. R-2 Low- to Medium-Density Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having medium population and housing density, single-family residential character and additional undeveloped land where it is desirable and likely that similar development will occur. All uses permitted of right in the R-1 district are also permitted in the R-2 district. D. R-3 Medium-Density Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having a medium population and housing density, residential character and additional undeveloped land where it is desirable and likely that similar development will occur. Multifamily residential units in the form of duplex apartments may be permitted by special use only. All uses permitted of right in the R-1 and R-2 districts are permitted in the R-3 district. E. R-4 Medium- to High-Density Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having a high population and housing density, located where they can be well served by public and commercial facilities. Site area requirements are graduated to reflect the relative need for open space of the various types of residences based on expected family composition. Multifamily residential units in the form of duplex apartments are permitted by right. All uses permitted of right in the R-1, R-2, and R-3 districts are permitted. F. R-5 High-Density Residential. This district is composed of certain areas having high population, located where they can be well served by public and commercial facilities. Multifamily units as well as duplex, triplex and quadraplex units are allowed in this district. Detached single-family dwelling residential housing is excluded from this district, with the exception of a manufactured home community, which may be allowed as a special use. G. FA Forest, Agriculture. This district is intended to preserve the present rural residential character of certain land within the city, and to promote development of a type which does not require extensive public facilities and services. H. C-1 Local Commercial. This district is composed of certain lands and structures used primarily for the retailing of goods and the furnishing of selected services to nearby residential areas. Regulations within this district are intended to permit limited development of the necessary commercial uses while at the same time protecting nearby residential properties from possible adverse effects of the business activities. At such time as the development of presently undeveloped portions of the city warrants provision of additional facilities, prior to making a recommendation to the mayor and council, the zoning board will evaluate applications for such local commercial districts on the basis of the following criteria: 1. The development of a local commercial district, at the location proposed and in the manner proposed, will not adversely affect abutting residential properties. 2. The site development plan provides for adequate vehicular and pedestrian access and circulation, and the resulting concentration of vehicular traffic will not present problems of safety or unduly impede normal traffic movement on adjacent residential streets. 3. The need for the limited commercial district is justified on the basis of facts submitted by the applicant which clearly indicates that a present or imminent trade market exists for the type and extent of facility proposed and that existing general commercial districts (or districts already zoned but not yet developed) do not adequately satisfy the need for such commercial service. I. C-2 General Commercial. This district is composed of certain land and structures used to provide for the general retailing of goods and the furnishing of major services to the citizens of Manchester and the surrounding region. This district occupies a central location, is intended to serve a wide trade area, and offers a wide range of services and merchandise. The future expansion of this district should only occur as an increase in depth and intensity of use rather than continued strip-like extensions along major streets. It is expected that in the future most commercial uses requiring this district classification will occur as planned shopping centers occupying presently undeveloped acreage located in proximity and with access to major thoroughfares. J. I-C Institutional-Church. This district is composed of real property owned by a recognized religious body. Further, the property owned, if consisting of more than one lot, must be contiguous to the sanctuary or in a continuum of property lots which form an unbroken continuity back to the sanctuary in order to be so designated. (A "break" caused by a street, road, or highway will not be considered a break in continuum.) Property also owned but not satisfying this definition will be designated based on its location elsewhere within the city. At such times as a religious body wishes to divest itself of such designated property or at such time as a religious body wishes to use one or more of its so-designated parcels, it may petition the planning and zoning board for a new designation of such property prior to the beginning of the disposal of the property prior to a "use" change. In this manner, the property, or the parcels, can be realigned with the contiguous district, or districts, prior to the sale or other disposal of such property, or prior to a "use" change. K. I-G Institutional-government. This district is composed of real property owned by a government-municipal, county, state or federal. Those properties which are leased by a government will be excluded from this designation and will be designated based on the compatible uses in the surrounding area. Also excluded from this designation are properties held by a government by way of foreclosure for whatever reason. At such times as a government wishes to divest itself of such designated property, it shall petition the planning and zoning board for a new designation of such property prior to the beginning of the disposal of the property. In this manner, the property can be realigned with the contiguous district, or districts, prior to the sale or other disposal of such property. L. I-1 Light Industrial. This district includes areas which are well adapted to industrial development but where proximity to residential or commercial districts, or other exposure, makes it desirable to limit the manner and intensity of industrial operations. The purpose of this district is to permit the normal operation of the majority of industrial uses under conditions of operation which will protect the other uses in the district as well as nearby residential and commercial uses. This district is not designed for residential use and such use is prohibited. M. I-2 Heavy Industrial. This district includes areas which are well adapted to relatively intense forms of industrial use. Controls on the conditions of operations of plants in this district are less stringent than in the I-1 district, since location of I-2 districts makes it unlikely that they will adversely affect less intensive uses. This district is not designed for residential use and such use is prohibited. N. Historic Business District. This classification shall serve as an overlay within the C-1 and C-2 commercial districts to recognize and protect those buildings and structures having historic significance or otherwise qualifying for historic preservation tax-credits. In addition to meeting all criteria of the zoning classification in which the building or structure is situated, further regulations as established by a historic preservation ordinance, which ordinance shall identify or classify affected properties, shall apply. O. Flood Hazard/Wetland/Slope Protection. This classification shall serve as an overlay within every zoning district to recognize and protect environmentally sensitive lands subject to flooding, statutory wetlands (where determination of the wetland has been made known to the city), and those areas where due to topography, degree of slope and soil conditions there exists an increased likelihood of environmental damage. Permitting by the city for land disturbing activities, including grading, clear-cutting of timber, and construction activities, may be limited or prohibited by applicable federal and state laws. It is incumbent on every property owner and applicant for a development activity permit within the city to familiarize himself with these laws and their applicability to the subject property. It is not the duty of city officials to assess or evaluate construction plans for applicability of these laws, nor shall the city, its officers and employees, be liable in money damages to any owner or applicant who seeks or secures its permission to engage in any prohibited activity on or affecting such lands. Overlaying of areas previously identified or determined by the proper regulatory agency on the official zoning maps of the City of Manchester is intended to be a public service only and to place property owners on notice of those areas where special development criteria may be applicable. A flood hazard area shall correspond to area identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) on its most recent official flood hazard maps for the area encompassing the City of Manchester in Meriwether and Talbot counties. General construction within an identified flood hazard area is prohibited, except as meets the criteria of federal, state and local flood management regulations. A statutory wetland is defined as "those areas that are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions." This definition requires evidence of three conditions: (1) presence of water during the growing season, (2) presence of hydric soil, and (3) a prevalence of vegetation adaptive to wet conditions. Permitting of activities in or adjacent to statutory wetlands, and the enforcement of violations of the laws pertaining to wetland protection is within the jurisdiction of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and the Georgia Department of Natural Resources. Recognizing the existence of the Pine Mountain Ridge within the corporate limits of the City of Manchester, certain federal and state regulations may restrict, limit, or prohibit development activities where the degree of slope is so steep as to increase the likelihood of damage to the environment. Factors such as soil type, subsurface conditions, and natural vegetation may influence applicability of these laws and regulations to a specific property. It is the policy of the city to encourage sound and reasonable stewardship of the land, particularly in a manner which protects water quality from runoff that creates erosion and carries sedimentation, while balancing that interest against the owner's right to the use and enjoyment of his property. Persons applying to the city for permits to engage in land-disturbing activities or to permit construction on the Pine Mountain Ridge are encouraged to familiarize themselves with all pertinent laws and regulations and seek compliance therewith prior to applying for a permit from the city. (Ord. of 1-9-2015) Section 503. - Uses permitted in zoning districts. The uses permitted in each of the zoning districts shall only be those listed below. In the event that a use is proposed that is not specifically named below, a recommendation to amend the text of this ordinance may be obtained from the Manchester Planning and Zoning Commission subject to the approval of the Manchester Mayor and Council. 503.1. R-E Estate Residential. • Single-family dwellings, on a permanent foundation; • Accessory uses and buildings; • Off-street parking and loading for vehicles in operating condition only, with current tags affixed. • Public utility installations and lands. 503.2. R-1 Low-Density Residential. • Single-family dwelling on a permanent foundation; • Public parks, playgrounds, community buildings, and similar public service facilities serving residential areas; • Schools, public and private; • Accessory use and buildings; • Off-street parking and loading for vehicles in operating condition only, with current tag affixed; • Public utility installations and lands. Special use: • Bed and breakfast establishment. Criteria for special uses: Compatibility to neighborhood Minimum traffic impact Adequacy of parking 503.3. R-2 Low- to Medium-Density Residential. • Same uses permitted in R-1 zoning district; Special uses: • Privately operated day nurseries, preschools, and kindergartens provided the play area is enclosed to a height of four feet; • Physicians, dentists, and chiropractic offices; • Professional offices; • Bed and breakfast establishment; • Attached single-family dwelling. 503.4. R-3 Medium-Density Residential. • Same uses as permitted in R-2 zoning district; • Manufactured homes. Special uses: • Roominghouse or boardinghouse, bed and breakfast establishment; • Duplex dwelling; • Attached single-family dwelling. 503.5. R-4 Medium- to High-Density Residential. • Manufactured homes; • Same uses permitted in R-3 zoning district; • Duplex dwellings: Special use: • Attached single-family dwelling. 503.6. R-5 High-Density Residential. • Manufactured homes; • Duplex dwellings; • Triplex dwelling • Quadraplex dwellings; • Multifamily apartment dwellings; • Roominghouse or boardinghouse, and bed and breakfast establishment. Special uses: (1) Manufactured Home Community. 503.7. FA Forest, Agriculture. • Any usual agricultural activity provided such activity does not include a confinement feeding operation; • Commercial tree plantings; • Temporary or portable sawmills for the cutting of timber provided no machine operation is established closer than 200 feet to any property line; • Sale of products of commodities raised on the premises provided no structure for such sales shall be closer than 30 feet to any property line; and all structures and displays shall be removed at the end of the sale or within one year of their construction; • Riding stables and academies provided that any structure or enclosure housing animals shall be at least 100 feet from any property line; • Golf courses, parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, lakes, swimming pools, country clubs, and other similar facilities, whether public or private, for recreational purposes; • Single-family and two-family (duplex) dwellings on a permanent foundation with the square-footage at least equal to the existing square-footage required in the contiguous residential zoning district; if there is more than one contiguous district, then the petitioner may select which of the contiguous districts will govern the square-footage requirement; • Home occupations. Special uses: (1) Secondary detached residences; (2) Cemeteries; (3) Agricultural-related structures. 503.8. C-1 Local Commercial. • Retail and convenience stores, except sale of gasoline, conducive to neighborhood needs; • Restaurants, except drive-in restaurants; • Roominghouses or boardinghouses, bed and breakfast establishment; • Amusement and recreational businesses, including theaters; • Business, music, art, and dancing schools; • Personal businesses and professional services; • Copy services; • Medical clinics and veterinarian's offices but not including outside kennels; • Drugstores; • Gift shops; • Florists; • Laundry and dry cleaning services, including coin-operated laundromats; Special uses: • Nursing homes, rest homes, and sanitoriums; • Residential use. 503.9.
