Section 501A. - Manufactured home parks. 501A-1 Procedures for Development. All manufactured home parks developed after adoption of this ordinance shall meet the following site plan requirements: A. Site Plan Approval Required. All manufactured home park developments shall require site plan approval by the PZB in accordance with the procedures and requirements established herein. Site plans required herein for the placement of three or more residential units shall contain the seal of a Georgia Registered Engineer or Surveyor. No building permits shall be issued for sites within any development until final approval is granted subject to all park plan requirements. B. Park Plan Submittal Requirements. All park plans shall be submitted to the Building Inspector or Zoning Administrator accompanied by the required fee payment as established by the City of Manchester. C. The name of the proposed park, and the name, address and telephone number of the applicant. D. Location map and legal description of the manufactured home park, north arrow (designated magnetic or true). E. Complete plans to scale of one inch equals not more than 100 feet and specifications of the proposed park showing: ⇒ The area and dimensions of the tract of land; including topographic data at the contour interval of not more than five feet or an interval appropriate for decision making on the tract; and including the location and type of soils on the tract. Statement of accuracy signed by surveyor or engineer as applicable. ⇒ The number, location and dimensions of all manufactured home lots. ⇒ The location and width of streets; the location and size of drainage mechanisms proposed, including the size of each application drainage area. ⇒ The location of service buildings (laundry service, office, community building etc.) and other proposed structures. ⇒ The location of water and sewer lines and riser pipes. ⇒ Plans and specifications of the water supply and refuse and sewerage disposal facilities. ⇒ Plans and specifications of all buildings constructed or to be constructed with the park. ⇒ The location of street lights, if applicable. ⇒ The location of bulk refuse containers, perimeter walls, and park identification signs. ⇒ A soil erosion and sedimentation plan meeting the requirements of the Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Act. ⇒ Certification from the appropriate authority on water and sewer acceptability. F. Development Compliance. All required improvements, according to the site plan approved by the PZB, shall be installed in each phase before the issuance of building permits. 501A-2 Regulations. A. Soil and Ground Cover Requirements. Exposed ground surfaces in all parts of every manufactured home park shall adhere to the following: 1. All streets shall be constructed so as to reduce dust, and in accordance with stipulations as shall be required by the City Building Inspector to ensure properly constructed streets. 2. All areas designated as yards shall be plated with grass or acceptable vegetative shrubs or flowers. 3. Any walkways to front or back entrances shall be covered with stone or other solid material capable of preventing soil erosion and eliminating objectionable dust. B. Location and Frontage. A manufactured home park development shall be located on property with a minimum frontage of 50 feet on a public street. C. Site Drainage Requirements. The ground surface in all parts of every park site shall be graded and equipped to drain all water in a safe, efficient manner. D. Streets. All mobile manufactured home parks shall contain a street system designated to provide convenient circulation within the park, and shall have one unobstructed access to a public street or highway. The following requirements shall apply to the development of the park street system: 1. All internal streets shall meet the minimum requirements of the City of Manchester for all weather drives, and shall be a minimum of 20 feet in width. 2. All cul-de-sacs shall be constructed with a minimum 30-foot radius. 3. All park streets shall be maintained a state of good repair at all times by the owner(s) of the park. 4. Street design, base preparations, and surface construction materials shall meet the requirements of the county street and road standards. Written approval of the street system by the City Building Inspector shall be required before the first building permit is issued. E. Off-Street Parking Requirements. A minimum of two off-street parking spaces per lot shall be provided in all manufactured home parks for the use of park occupants and guest. F. Lot Area and Width. A manufactured home park development shall have a minimum area of ten contiguous acres with 30 percent for streets and other improvements. Individual unit spaces shall consist of 4,000 s.f. per unit. Individual unit spaces shall comply with per unit minimum for Multi-Family Districts as stated in Section 504 G. Setbacks Required: 1. No manufactured home or accessory building or structure shall be located closer than 30 feet to any park perimeter property boundary. 2. Each manufactured home shall be setback from any other manufactured home by at least 20 feet. 3. There shall be a minimum distance of 20 feet between any individual manufactured home and an adjoining street, common parking areas, or other common areas. H. Perimeter Buffer Required. An Undisturbed buffer consisting of trees and other landscaping material at least 30 feet in width shall be provided and maintained around the entire exterior perimeter of a manufactured home park. Provided, however, any underground utilities may be placed within this buffer, but no closer than 20 feet from the perimeter of the park boundary. The property owner shall be responsible for the maintenance of the buffer, which shall be so maintained as to present a neat and orderly appearance and shall be kept free from refuse and debris. I. Lighting. All manufactured home parks shall have lighting of height, spacing and intensity so that each home site's access and parking is appropriately illuminated. Mercury vapor, or high or low pressure sodium lights shall be installed at not more than 200 feet intervals with a minimum height of 18 feet. J. Water Supply. 1. Governmental Water System: All manufactured home parks shall connect to an existing public water system if such system is located within 1,000 feet of the proposed park. The availability and adequacy of a public water supply shall be confirmed by the applicable agency having jurisdiction. If the public water supply is determined to be unavailable or inadequate for service, the Planning Commission may waive the requirement and allow an alternative water supply source. 2. Individual Water System: If individual wells are used, each well may be permitted to serve up to four service connections, provided that the construction method of each well shall meet the standards in accordance with the Georgia Annotated Code 12-5-138. The Water Well Standard Act of 1991, as amended. K. Sewerage Disposal and Treatment: All manufactured home parks shall be required to exist to the existing city sewer system. L. Electrical: All electric installations shall meet the requirements of the current National Electric Code, as amended. M. Refuse Collection Facilities: Each manufactured home park shall be provided with a sanitary method of solid waste collection and disposal. Collection facilities shall be either in the form of bulk containers (dumpsters) of sufficient size and adequately distributed throughout the park to meet the needs of the park residents, or at least one individually covered refuse containers having a capacity of 30 gallons or more for each occupied lot. Bulk containers shall either be enclosed with a minimum of four feet high chain link fence and placed upon a concrete pad, with adequate draining to cities sewer, extending at least 18 inches around each container perimeter. Refuse areas shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary manner so as not to attract, harbor or breed insects, rodents, or any manner of vermin or pest. N. Service Buildings: Accessory structures and community service facilities are hereby permitted for the convenience and well-being of park residents. Such structures shall conform to the Georgia State Building Codes adopted by the City of Manchester, as amended, and may include, but are not limited to the following uses: 1. Park management offices, repair shops, and storage. 2. Community postal facilities. 3. Indoor community recreation areas. 4. Commercial uses supplying essential goods or services for park residents. O. Miscellaneous Requirements: 1. Listings of Manufactured Home Required: Every person, or other entity owning or operating a manufactured home park, and each such entity engaged in the sale or rental of manufactured homes or lots upon which to place them, shall furnish the Tax Commissioner of Meriwether County on January 1 and July 1 of each year with a complete list of all manufactured homes parked or rented or otherwise located upon the property of the entity or in a park operated by an entity. 2. Restrictions on Occupancy: A manufactured home shall not be occupied for dwelling purposes unless it has met the installation requirements in this ordinance upon inspection by the Building Inspector of the City of Manchester. P. Underpinning. Each Manufactured Home must be underpinned. Installation shall be in accordance with the manufacturers installation instructions. Acceptable materials include masonry, stone, metal, medium or heavy gauge vinyl or other materials manufactured for the purpose of underpinning and approved by Building Inspector. CHAPTER 1. - PURPOSE, AUTHORITY AND JURISDICTION
Section 1.01. - Purpose and scope. These regulations are to provide for the orderly growth and development of the City of Manchester and in accordance with the City of Manchester Zoning Ordinance. The primary purposes of the development ordinance are: A. To provide for safe and efficient traffic circulation by development of a coordinated street system in relation to major streets, adjoining subdivisions, and public facilities; B. To achieve subdivision of larger tracts into building lots of reasonable utility and livability; C. To provide for the acceptance of land for public rights-of-way; D. To provide for the installation and construction of utilities, streets, stormwater management facilities, and other public improvements essential to service land being subdivided; E. To assure that public improvements will be constructed according to safe and durable standards; F. To enable the dedication or reservation of land for public schools, parks, and other public purposes; G. To assure that development will occur within an environmentally compatible setting and free of flood hazards; H. To provide for the subdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land; and I. To establish the procedure for submittal, approval, and recording of subdivision plats within the City of Manchester. Section 1.02. - Authority. This chapter is adopted by the mayor and council pursuant to authority granted by the Constitution and laws of the State of Georgia. Section 1.03. - Jurisdiction. These regulations shall govern the development of land within incorporated areas of the City of Manchester. The Manchester City Manager shall have the final decision on subdivision plats within the city. CHAPTER 2. - INTERPRETATION
Section 2.01. - Minimum requirements. The provisions contained in this chapter shall be considered as minimum requirements. When this chapter imposes greater restrictions than are imposed by other provisions of law or ordinance, this chapter shall prevail. Section 2.02. - Definitions. Certain terms and words are defined for the purpose of this chapter. Words used in the present tense shall include the future. The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is permissive. a. As-built plans. Detailed construction plans showing completed improvements as constructed. b. Boulevard. A street developed with two one-way pavements separated by a landscaped median. c. City. The City of Manchester, Georgia. d. Cluster residential development project. A residential development that provides for the grouping attached and detached residential dwellings on lots that may be smaller than allowed in a zoning district, for the purpose of preserving open space and natural terrain features, and economy in providing public facilities and services. On certain cluster home residential developments, fire-resistant materials may be required. [e. Reserved.] f. Commercial/office subdivision. A subdivision developed with streets and other improvements intended to serve lots for commercial and office development. g. Comprehensive plan. The Manchester Comprehensive Plan adopted pursuant to the Georgia Planning Act of 1989, indicates the location and extent of future land uses, public facilities, transportation, and the city's long range development policies. h. County. Meriwether County, Georgia or Talbot County, Georgia. i. Covenant. An agreement or restriction placed on lots by a developer governing future land use or development which binds future purchasers of the lots. j. Cul-de-sac. A dead-end local street opened at one end and closed at the other by a permanent, circular turnaround. k. Crosswalk. A right-of-way within a block dedicated to public use, intended primarily for pedestrian use designed to provide access to adjacent roads and lots. l. Dead-end street. A local street open at one end and closed at the other. Dead-end streets may have a cul-de-sac at the closed end, a "T" or "Y" turnaround, or dead-end for future extension to adjacent properties. m. Dedication plat. A plat required for the dedication to the city of rights-of-way for streets, public easements for utilities, and other public improvements drawn in accordance with the Georgia Plat Act and suitable for recording. n. Development permit. A permit issued by the city manager for construction of subdivision improvements and other development, including soil erosion and sedimentation control, rough clearing and grading, street and drainage construction, and storm water management. o. Easement. A right granted by a property owner to the general public, a public utility, the city, or a private individual or corporation for the use of a portion of the owner's land for a specific purpose, or use as a means of access to other property. Easements shall be designated "public" or "private" depending upon the nature of the usage. p. Engineer. A licensed professional engineer in the State of Georgia and registered through the State Board of Professional Engineers who is competent in the field of civil design. q. Flood hazard area. The area threatened by periodic flooding as determined by data and maps provided by the Federal Emergency Management Administration, U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, U.S. Soil Conservation Service, U.S. Army Corps Engineers, or hydrological studies utilizing generally accepted engineering practices. Flood hazard areas shall include all land underneath a permanent body of water, e.g., a lake, pond, river, and stream, and all land within the limits of a flood having a 100-year return frequency or better. Regulations for flood hazard areas are contained in the Manchester Flood Damage Prevention Ordinance. r. County health department. The department responsible for enforcement of county health regulations including the issuance of permits for on-site sewage disposal systems and wells. s. Improvements. Physical changes to the land which are necessary to create useable lots including (but not limited to) grading and paving streets, sewer and water facilities, hydrants, sidewalks, monuments, changes to existing utilities, and stormwater drainage and detention systems. t. Improvements, construction plans. Detailed construction plans prepared by a professional engineer or landscape architect registered in the State of Georgia, for streets, including typical cross sections and grade profiles and elevations, layout and elevations of water and sanitary sewer facilities, along with drainage and stormwater management facilities, and soil erosion control. u. Industrial subdivision. A subdivision developed with streets and other improvements intended to serve lots for industrial development, also known as planned industrial district or industrial park. v. Landscape architect. A licensed professional landscape architect in the State of Georgia who is competent in the field of civil design. w. Lot, building. A lot of record, or any combination of lots of record, held in single ownership, or in common ownership by more than one, which meets minimum lot area requirements established by the zoning district in which a given tract of land is located. x. Lot, corner. A lot having frontage on two or more public streets at their intersection. y. Lot divisions. The division of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots. Lot must have minimum frontage on a city or county road, and comply with the Manchester Zoning Ordinance. z. Lot of record. A lot which is drawn on an approved subdivision plat recorded in the office of the Meriwether or Talbot County Clerk of Superior Court, or a parcel described by metes and bounds, the description of which has been so recorded. aa. Lot width. The distance between side lot lines, measured along the front yard building setback line as established by the Manchester Zoning Ordinance. bb. Marginal access street. A local residential street paralleling and adjacent to a major arterial which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. cc. City manager. The chief administrator for the city. The city manager is appointed by the mayor and council. Functions assigned to the city manager under this ordinance may be delegated by him, in writing, with approval of the mayor and council, to another employee of the city working under supervision of the city manager. dd. Mayor and council. The elected governing body for the city. Referred to as "city council" in this chapter. ee. Building and code enforcement department. The department responsible for administration and enforcement of the building codes and related construction codes, business licenses and issuance of development permits, soil erosion and sedimentation control, and construction inspections under direction of the city manager. This department is also responsible for administration of the comprehensive development plan, the zoning ordinance, development ordinance, stormwater management ordinance, landscape ordinance, and long-range development planning, under the direction of the city manager. ff. Manchester Planning and Zoning Board. A board comprised of citizens appointed by the mayor and council to review and make recommendations on zoning, subdivision, and long range development plans. Referred to as the "PZB" in this ordinance. gg. Manchester Public Works Department. The department responsible for design review construction inspection, and maintenance of streets, of water and sewer facilities within the city. hh. Manchester Utilities Department. The department responsible for design review and construction inspection and operation of utilities and related facilities approved by the city. ii. Pavement width. The cross section width of a paved road measured from edges of pavement. jj. Perennial stream. Any stream which flows throughout the entire year, sometimes shown as a solid blue line on a United States Geological Survey (USGS) 7-minute Topographic Series Maps (1:24,000). kk. Planned Unit Development (PUD). Development intended to encourage both residential and nonresidential land uses according to a master development plan, with related covenants and restrictions. Developments with PUD project may have flexibility in the application of development standards when approved according to a master development plan, and to promote the conservation of natural resources, and more efficient use of land. ll. Plan. A developer's plan for the subdivision and development of land submitted to the city for approval under the ordinance, consisting of a minimum of: 1. Preliminary plat. A plan showing the basic design and layout of the subdivision. 2. Construction improvement plans in conformance with this chapter for all public improvements. 3. Final plat. A plat of a development with legal description of all lots, easements, and rights-of-way sufficient to reproduce the plat in the field, and which meets the requirements of the Georgia Plat Act. The final plat is intended for legal recording of lots, rights-of-way, easements, and restrictive covenants. mm. Public open space. Land dedicated or reserved for use by the general public. It includes parks, recreation facilities, school sites, community or public building sites and similar spaces for public use. nn. Public utility. Firms, corporations, or local government authorities providing gas, electricity, telecommunications service, and similar essential services. oo. Road, city. Any road-paved or unpaved which is maintained by the city. pp. Road, county. Any road-paved or unpaved which is maintained by Meriwether or Talbot County. qq. Road, private. A road that is not maintained by the city or Meriwether or Talbot County. Private roads are under the ownership of private entities and maintained by individual property owners. rr. Sewer, lateral. Sanitary sewer collection lines within a subdivision or development that transports effluent to larger trunk sewers for sewage treatment. ss. Sewer, trunk. Main sanitary sewer lines which collect sewage from lateral sewer lines for transportation either directly to sewage treatment plants or to larger interceptor sewers entering a treatment plant. tt. Sight distance; intersection sight distance. Sight distance for intersections with minor/major arterial roads use intersection sight distance measured from a driver's eye height of 3.5 feet to an object height of 4.25 feet. uu. Sight distance; stopping distance relative to street design. The unobstructed vision on a horizontal plane along a street centerline from a driver-eye height of 3.5 feet and an object height of six inches. vv. Soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. A plan for temporary and permanent facilities to control soil erosion and sedimentation from subdivision construction sites and commercial and industrial development sites, as required by the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance, and the rules and regulations of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources Environmental Protection Division. ww. Streets. A street includes the land between the right-of-way lines, whether improved or unimproved, and may be comprised of pavement, shoulders, curb and gutter, sidewalks, drainage ditches and structures within the street right-of-way lines. Streets are classified as follows: 1. Expressway. The expressway system includes high volume limited access thoroughfares through the county and region beyond. 2. Major arterial. An arterial street which is designed or intended for moderate to high levels of traffic flow within the city and county and region beyond and also includes the state and national highway system in the city and county. 3. Minor arterial. An arterial street similar in function of a major arterial but which is intended to provide moderate levels of traffic flow and greater access to abutting properties. Minor arterials serve as traffic feeder to major arterials and for cross-county and regional traffic. 4. Collector street. A street which carries traffic from local streets to minor and major arterial streets, and may include the principal entrance of a development. 5. Local street. A street designed to provide access to adjoining properties within a subdivision or other development. 6. Stub street. A dead-end street at adjoining property lines intended for future extension to serve the development of adjoining areas. xx. Stub-out service. Sanitary sewer connection facilities within the street right-of-way provided from lateral sewer line to the private property line for connection to building sewer lines. yy. Subdivision. The division of a parcel or tract of land for the purpose of creating sites for development, the rearrangement of existing lot lines, or transfer of ownership. zz. Subdivision re-plat. A plat submitted for changes in the arrangement of existing lots, rights-of-way or improvements in an existing approved and recorded subdivision. aaa. Surveyor. A registered land surveyor in the State of Georgia registered by the state board of licensing. bbb. Townhouse residential development project. A residential development project (as part of a PUD) that includes attached residential dwellings sharing common walls with fire rating according to the life safety code, and which are planned for individual ownership of the dwelling units and land thereafter. ccc. Utilities. Gas, electrical, and telecommunications facilities installed by a public utility company, or local government authorities. ddd. Wetlands. Areas defined as wetlands by federal law and regulations. eee. Zoning ordinance. The official zoning ordinance and zoning map as adopted by the mayor and council. CHAPTER 3. - PROCEDURE
Section 3.01. - Generally. Within the territorial limits of this city, no person shall subdivide or rearrange a lot line of any lot or parcel of land, grade and install streets and utilities, or make other improvements to the land without complying with the provisions of this chapter. The Meriwether or Talbot County Clerk of Superior Court shall record no final subdivision plat unless the same has been approved as provided herein. No building permits shall be issued and no public improvements or services shall be authorized or installed in any unapproved subdivision. The review and approval process of a subdivision shall include a pre-application conference and preliminary plan, construction improvements plans, soil erosion and sedimentation control plan, and a final plat. "As-built" construction plans for public improvements are required to be submitted with the subdivider's final plat. Section 3.02. - Pre-application conference and preliminary plan. A. Purpose of conference. The subdivider shall consult with the city manager for advice and assistance prior to preparation of the preliminary plat and application for approval. This will enable the subdivider to become familiar with the approval process, required documents, inspections, the comprehensive plan, subdivisions improvement standards adopted by the city council, and development factors which may impact the immediate area near the subdivision. For subdivisions that require access onto a state highway, the subdivider is required to consult with the district engineer for the Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT). The subdivider shall consult with the public works director for access onto city streets, and for improvements to existing streets. B. Presentation of preliminary plan review. The subdivider shall be prepared to present a preliminary plan at or following the pre-application conference. The preliminary concept plan shall be a general design of the proposed subdivision including boundaries of the proposed subdivision, topographic contours, layout of lots and streets, size and dimensions of the property and proposed lots [including lot area], open space and other planned improvements. C. [ Review and transmit; written response. ] Following the pre-application conference the city manager in consultation with the planning and zoning board (PZB) shall review the preliminary plan and transmit the subdivider within 15 working days a written response, providing the following information: 1. Conformance to standards in the zoning ordinance. 2. Conformance of the proposed subdivision to the comprehensive plan and any other plans and development policies of the city. 3. Any recommendations or reports from the city engineer or other city departments. 4. Any additional information relative to the subdivision approval process or development standards. 5. Recommendations to improve the development and design of the subdivision. Section 3.03. - Zoning compliance. A. The city manager in consultation with the PZB shall determine that the proposed subdivision meets the requirements of the Manchester Zoning Ordinance and the property is in the correct zoning district. Following written notification by the city manager that the proposed preliminary plan complies with the zoning ordinance and the requirements of this chapter, and recommendations for improving the development, the subdivider may proceed with preparing a construction improvement plan as provided in this chapter. B. If the property is not in the correct zoning district for the proposed subdivision development, the subdivider shall submit an application for rezoning according to the procedures of the Manchester Zoning Ordinance. The preliminary plan for the proposed subdivision shall be submitted with the rezoning application for review and recommendation by the PZB, and action by the city council. Section 3.04. - Construction improvement plan; filing and review procedures, plan review fee. A. The subdivider shall file with the city manager seven copies of the construction improvement plan. A plan review fee of $500.00 shall be paid by the subdivider at the time of submission. The construction improvements plan shall be reviewed by various city departments, including the public works department, the water and sewer department, building and code enforcement department; police department, fire department; and any other city and county organizations that will be impacted by the subdivision. The city manager shall notify the school district about the proposed subdivision. The plan review process shall determine compliance with the regulations of this ordinance and the zoning ordinance and make any changes necessary to improve the subdivision. 1. If the plans are determined to be incomplete or otherwise deficient by the city, they shall be returned to the subdivider for changes and corrections. 2. If the plans are approved with modifications, the changes shall be indicated on the plat. A copy of the plans with changes indicated shall be returned to the subdivider who shall have the revisions made by the engineer who prepared the plans. 3. Once the preliminary plan has been reviewed and required revisions, if any, are made, the preliminary plat shall be submitted to the PZB and subsequently to the city council for final approval. 4. Following review and approval of the preliminary plat by the PZB and approval by the city council, the subdivider shall proceed with construction improvements plans. Section 3.05. - Construction improvements plan/plat; required information. A. The plat shall have the following information: 1. Description: a. Proposed name of subdivision, including unit, phase, and lines separating phases and/or units. b. Names, addresses, and telephone numbers of subdivider, engineer, landscape architect, and surveyor. Show 24-hour contact person. c. Graphic scale, north arrow, and date: the north point shall be identified as magnetic, true, or grid north. d. Location map showing the relationship of the subdivision site to the surrounding area, including directions and distances to readily identifiable landmarks in the surrounding area. e. Acreage to be subdivided. f. Number of lots. g. Density in dwellings per acre [gross]. h. Total lineal feet of roads [per phase and total]. i. Zoning district of the property, including all setback provisions, as well as any special conditions of zoning imposed by the city (i.e., lots sizes, number of lots, minimum house size). 2. Existing conditions: a. Topographic contours and vertical intervals of not more than two feet when a new street is involved in a subdivision including outline of wooded areas, vegetation, and surface drainage. b. Topographic data shall be based on field survey or aerial survey. c. Deed record names and addresses of adjoining property owners or subdivision, along with zoning of the adjacent parcels. d. In case of a re-subdivision, a copy of existing plat with proposed resubdivision imposed thereon. e. Show whether or not any portion of the project is in a 100-year flood plain or contains known statutory wetlands. f. Location of existing and platted property lines, location, width, and names of all platted roads, railroads, utility rights-of-way, public areas, existing buildings or structures. g. Existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the tract or within the right-of-way of boundary roads with sizes, grades, and invert elevations from field surveys or other sources. All sizes and data on all utilities shall be provided. h. Location of streams, lakes, wetlands, and land subject to a 100-year flood hazard, including contour elevations. State if elevations are taken from a surveyed stream on a FEMA map or if the elevations are from an independent study (HEX-2, QUICK-2, etc.). Wetland areas shall be field located. i. Notation that live streams and/or wetlands lie/do not lie within this subdivision, or unit, or phase. Provide a copy of wetlands delineation report from a registered soil scientist in the State of Georgia. j. Existing drainage patterns. The boundaries of the pre-developed drainage basins shall be shown on a map. The map shall include the number of acres in each basin, the pre-developed runoff coefficient, and the time of concentration. 3. Proposed conditions: a. Layout and names of proposed roads, alleys, public walkways/bikeways (i.e., sidewalks, trails, paths, bicycle facilities), with width of pavement and rights-of-way. b. Lot dimensions, including lot area. Lots with detention ponds must meet minimum zoning area requirements outside the area of the detention pond. Show all existing and proposed easements. Show drainage easements for storm drainage pipes which cross individual lots. c. Flood elevations on any lots within a 100-year flood hazard area. In addition, the foundation footing elevation that is a minimum of one foot above the established 100-year flood elevation shall be shown. This data may be shown either on the lot layout or in tabular form. d. Construction plans of streets including typical cross section and grade profiles. Show percent of each grade and length of each vertical curve. The minimum centerline stopping sight distance for interior streets is 200 feet. e. Show the centerline stopping distance for all points of access onto county roads. Show posted speed limit of existing roads. f. Construction plans of storm drainage systems with pipe sizes, length, grade, location of outlets, runoff and velocity calculations, etc. All storm drainage systems carrying off-site runoff shall be designed for the 100-years storm event. All storm pipes within the county right-of-way shall be asphalt coated corrugated metal pipe. g. Improvements construction plan of water supply system with pipe sizes and location of hydrants, valves, and all appurtenances. h. Improvement construction plan of sanitary sewers with grades, service, pipe size, and points of discharge and connection to other trunk or lateral sewers. i. Easements for drainage and future sanitary sewers along all side and rear lot lines. j. Proposed soil erosion and sedimentation control. k. Final contours. In some cases, the street profiles will suffice in showing the amount of cut and fill; however, in many cases, final contours need to be shown on the plans. l. Stormwater management. A hydrological study should be included and the necessary outlet control structures should be shown on the plan. No increase in runoff or velocity will be permitted. Attach engineer's certification that the improvements will not adversely impact downstream properties. m. Proposed drainage patterns. The boundaries of the post-developed drainage basins shall be shown on a map. The map shall include the number of acres in each basin, the post-developed runoff coefficient, and the time of concentration. n. Show a five-foot high fence on all detention ponds with a 100-year ponding elevation over four feet. o. Detail drawings. Any structural practice used should be explained and illustrated with detail drawings and must, at a minimum, meet city standards. p. Show the following notes on all plans: 1) A 20-foot storm sewer and sanitary sewer easement exists along each property line and along each lot line, centered on lot lines, for future drainage lines. 2) All storm drains shall be extended a minimum of 30 feet behind any future residence or building. 3) Grade stakes shall be set on all streets prior to any street grading. An as-built subgrade centerline profile shall be submitted and approved by city prior to the installation of curb and gutter or waterlines. 4) An as-built detention pond detail and revised hydro study shall be submitted to the city prior to installation of the water line or curb and gutter. 5) All undisturbed buffers shall be field located; staked and flagged or marked with "tenzar" (or similar type fencing); and shall be submitted to the city for approval prior to grading. Section 3.06. - Soil erosion, sedimentation and drainage plan; filing and review procedures. A. At or following submission of the construction improvements plan, the developer shall file for approval a soil erosion, sedimentation, and drainage plan prepared in accordance with the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance. No permit shall be issued by the city, nor shall any other land-distributing activity commence upon the tract to be developed until this plan has been reviewed and approved by the natural resource conservation district. B. If the tract to be developed consists of five or more acres, or is part of a common plan of development of five acres or more the developer shall additionally demonstrate compliance with EPD General Permit No. GAR 100000 for stormwater discharges associated with construction activities. C. Once the construction improvements plans and soil erosion, sedimentation drainage plans have been reviewed that all required revisions, if any, are made, the plans will be approved by the city manager and the subdivider may apply for the issuance of development permit so that construction may begin in accordance with the requirements of chapter 4 [of this appendix]. Before issuing any permits the city manager shall require proof of all county, school and city taxes owing on the property have been paid. Cross reference— Soil erosion and sedimentation control, § 38-81 et seq. Section 3.07. - Final plat; filing and review procedures. A. Once the proposed improvements are substantially in place, and the subdivider has received a certificate of occupancy from the building and code enforcement department, the subdivider shall submit to the city manager four copies of the final plat for review and comment. The final plat shall conform substantially to the construction improvement plans as approved, and it shall include only that portion of the construction improvement plan that have been developed and is to be recorded, provided that it complies with all requirements of this ordinance. B. When the final plat has been approved by the city manager, the subdivider shall supply one original drawing of the final plat on mylar or sepia in black ink, as well as ten copies (blue lines) of the final plat prepared by a licensed professional engineer or landscape architect and a surveyor, minimum size 8½ inch by 11 inch, maximum size 17 inch by 22 inch. In addition, all other necessary documentation for recording must be submitted at this time. C. Once the final plat is approved by the city manager; one copy shall be recorded in the clerk of the superior court's office; and one copy each shall be provided to the county tax assessor's office; county board of education; county emergency-911 services; county voters registration; the postmaster general; and the utilities protection center. The building and code enforcement department shall retain the mylar and the remainder of the copies. D. The procedure for consideration of a final plat for approval by the city manager shall consist of the following steps: 1. Completion of public improvements. After completion of the physical development of the subdivision, the developer shall contact the building and code enforcement department for a checklist specifying the procedure in obtaining the various approval that will release the subdivision for final plat consideration. 2. As part of this process, the subdivider shall submit a final plat and as-built drawings, along with a two-year maintenance bond or letter of credit. Letters of credit from banks having local offices are preferred. All bonds or letters of credit shall be subject to approval by the city manager, who shall be authorized to reject a bond or letter of credit if he reasonably determines the obligor or surety is unreliable or there would be practical difficulties in enforcing the obligation of the bond or letter of credit. The bond or letter of credit shall name the City of Manchester as obligee. For residential subdivisions, the amount of the bond or letter of credit shall be equal of $15.00 per lineal foot of street. For commercial and industrial subdivisions, the amount of the bond or letter of credit shall be $25.00 per lineal foot of street footage for developments with sidewalks and $20.00 per lineal street footage for projects without sidewalks. The maintenance bond or letter of credit shall remain in effect for two years from the date of final plat approval. During the two-year period, it shall be the subdivider's responsibility to repair any defects that occur in the streets, sidewalks, drainage systems, and the storm water detention systems. 3. A maintenance bond or letter of credit shall be released at the end of the two-year period. Ninety days prior to expiration, a final inspection by the building and code enforcement department of all subdivision improvements will be performed to determine the need for any repairs. If repairs are necessary, the building and code enforcement department will notify the subdivider in writing. 4. If the subdivider fails to take the necessary action to make repairs within 30 days of notification by the city, then the city manager will authorize the surety or bank issuing the bond or letter of credit to release to the city all or any amount of funds needed to make repairs. Upon release of the funds, the public works department will take action to ensure that the necessary repairs to streets, sidewalks, drainage, or storm water detention facilities are completed. 5. The city manager may require the maintenance bond or letter of credit to be extended to ensure the completion of repairs started but not completed for a period not to exceed 180 days. Section 3.08. - Final plat; acceptance of public improvements. A. The final plat will be presented to the mayor and council for dedication of public improvements only after the following items have been submitted and completed: 1. Application for final plat approval. 2. Final plat prepared for recording drawn to the requirements of this chapter. 3. Copies of all material test results for base and asphalt paving. 4. Verification by the building and code enforcement department and public works department that all required inspections have been made and approved and the improvements to the subdivision, including street construction, sidewalks, drainage systems, and right-of-way seeding, are in compliance with approved plans, all underground utilities have been installed; and street and traffic signs are installed. 5. Verification that the soil erosion and sedimentation control for the subdivision is in compliance with the approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. 6. Verification by the water and sewer department that all requirements have been met, including submission of required documents and inspections. 7. Two-year maintenance bond or letter of credit. 8. As-built drawings of all water and sewage facilities submitted to and approved by the city engineer. 9. Septic system permits provided by the health department (for developments not using a sanitary sewer system). 10. As-built drawings of streets, and sidewalks, including: the existing center line profile of all newly constructed streets; and the top and invert elevations of all drainage structures. 11. As-built construction improvements plans for storm sewers with grade, pipe sizes and points of discharge. 12. As-built construction improvements plans for storm drainage system with grade, pipe sizes and location of outlets and other drainage structures, street profiles and storm water management facilities. 13. As-built construction improvements plans for water distribution systems with pipe sizes and locations of hydrants and valves. 14. Protective covenants or deed restrictions, if any, attached in form for recording. B. The as-built drawing(s) shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer or landscape architect and a surveyor at a minimum scale of 100 feet to the inch. Section 3.09. - Final plat; processing fee. Prior to the approval of the final plat by the city manager, the subdivider shall pay a fee of $50.00 per lot shown on the final plat to the City of Manchester. Section 3.10. - Final plat; required information. A. The final plat shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer or landscape architect and a surveyor, at a scale of 100 feet or less to the inch and shall provide the following information: 1. Name of the subdivision, including unit and/or phase of development (if applicable). 2. North point, scale, and date. 3. Names and addresses of the owners of record of the property to be subdivided. 4. Subdivider name, address, and phone number(s). 5. Name, addresses, phone number(s), and registration seal of the engineer or landscape architect and a surveyor who prepared the final plat. 6. Certification by surveyor that all monuments exist and their sizes, locations, and materials are correctly shown on the plat. 7. Legal description of the property including reference to land lot and district lines; street right-of-way lines; easements and other rights-of-way; property lines of lots and other sites with accurate dimensions to nearest 0.01 of a foot; bearings and angles on all lines; radii, arcs, and central angles of all curves with readings to the nearest minute. 8. Blocks designated by letter and lots by numerical order. 9. Current zoning, including setbacks and any special conditions placed on the rezoning of the property, or, stipulated in deed restrictions or restrictive covenants (i.e., minimum house size, type of construction). 10. The layout of the subdivision, including the following information: a. All street right-of-way boundaries, street names, addresses, tax identification numbers, bearings, angles of intersection, and right-of-way and easement widths. b. The lengths of all arcs, including radii, points of curvature, tangent bearings, and the length and bearing of the long cord of every arc. c. Drainage, sanitary sewer, and utility easements along all side and rear lot lines and natural or artificial watercourses as required in chapter 4 [of this appendix]. d. Detention pond maintenance and access easement to be shown, minimum 20 feet to a public right-of-way. e. Location of all storm drains including pipe sizes. f. Any buffer areas required in the zoning ordinance, including statements whether or not the buffer areas are to be landscaped, undisturbed, fenced, or a combination-type buffer. g. All lot lines measured to 0.01 of a foot. The bearings shall be indicated for all lot lines to the nearest second. The error of closure should not be less than one foot in 10,000.00 feet. h. Individual lot sizes measured in square feet. This figure may be placed on the lot or in a table with addresses and tax parcel identification numbers. All lots with detention ponds must meet the minimum zoning area requirements outside the area of the detention pond. i. The outline of all property to be dedicated or reserved for public use, or to be reserved for common use of all property owners in the subdivision with the purpose of the dedication or reservation indicated. This shall include cemeteries or grave sites as stated in section 4.45. j. Location of sidewalks and pedestrian and/or bicycle ways. k. Location and elevation of any 100-year flood hazard area, including the foundation elevation which is one foot above the established 100-year flood elevation for each lot located within the flood hazard area. This flood hazard area shall include both studied and unstudied streams, including drainage ways as designated on the preliminary plat. l. The following notations and certifications: Notation that "Live streams and/or wetlands lie (do not lie) within this subdivision, or unit and phase." If wetlands do lie within this subdivision, or unit and phase, the plat must include the following notation: "Wetlands shown on this plat are under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Lot owners may be subject to penalty of law for disturbance to these wetland areas without proper authorization." Notation that "The Lot owners may be subject to penalty of law for any unauthorized land distributing activity conducted on their property. Notation that "All storm drains shall be extended a minimum of 30 feet behind any future residence or building, and shall empty or drain into a sufficient drainage easement or watercourse."
