Section 3.11. - Lot divisions; generally. Lot divisions are the dividing of individual tracts of land into two or more separate lots without creating a subdivision as defined herein(no new street or utilities required). All lot divisions shall conform to the requirements of the Manchester Zoning Ordinance. The city manager shall have the authority to approve lot division. No building permit shall be issued for a tract of land created as the result of a lot division without the approval of the city manager. Section 3.12. - Lot divisions; required information. A plat shall be prepared by a registered engineer or landscape architect and surveyor, and shall provide the following information: 1. North arrow, scale, and date. 2. Names and addresses of the owners of record of the property to be subdivided. 3. Subdivider name and address. 4. Name, address, and registration seal of the surveyor who prepared the final plat. 5. Certification by a surveyor that all monuments exist and their size, locations, and materials are correctly shown on the plat. 6. Legal description of the property, including reference to land lot district lines; street right-of-way lines; easements and other rights-of-way; property lines of lots and other sites with accurate dimensions to nearest 0.01 of a foot; bearings and angles on all lines: radii, arcs, and central angles of all curves with readings to the nearest second. 7. Blocks designated by letter and lots by numerical order. 8. The layout of the lot division including the following information: a. All street right-of-way boundaries, street names, addresses, tax parcel identification numbers, bearings, angles of intersection, and right-of-way easement widths. b. The lengths of all arcs, including radii, points of curvature, tangent bearings, and the length and bearing of the long cord of every arc. c. Drainage and utility easements along all side and rear lot lines and watercourses, as required in Chapter 4, Improvements Standards [of this appendix]. d. All lot lines measured to nearest 0.01 of a foot. The bearings shall be indicated for all lot liens to the nearest second. The error of closure should not be less than one foot in 10,000 feet. e. Individual lot sizes measured in square feet. This figure may be placed on the lot or in a table with addresses and tax parcel identification numbers. 9. Current zoning, including the required setback lines by the zoning ordinance and any other setback lines established by public authority or stipulated in the deed restrictions. 10. Protective covenants or deed restrictions, if any, shall be placed directly on the final plat or attached in form for recording. 11. Soil survey prepared by a qualified, state-registered soil scientist and certified for approval by the health department. 12. Location and elevation of any 100-year flood hazard area, including the minimum foundation elevation for each lot affected by the 100-year flood hazard. 13. Statement on the existence of wetlands or live streams on the site. Section 3.13. - Dedication plats; generally. A plat is required for the dedication to the city of right-of-way and public improvements such as roads or sewer or water lines, and which will provide access or service to development, or which will serve future development in an area or sited for public facilities as described in chapter 5 [of this appendix]. The approval process for dedication plats shall be the same as for a final subdivision plat. A two-year maintenance bond or letter of credit shall be required for all public improvements as required for final plats. Section 3.14. - Dedication plats; required information. The plat shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer or landscape architect and a surveyor at a scale of 100 feet or less to the inch and shall provide the following information: 1. An accurate legal description of the property to be dedicated, including reference land lot lines. 2. The names and addresses of the owners of record of the property, the subdivider, and the engineer or landscape architect and surveyor who prepared the plat. The registration seal of the engineer or landscape architect and surveyor shall be on the plat. 3. North arrow, scale, and date. 4. The locations, widths, and names of any platted streets and easements adjacent to the property. 5. The locations, sizes, and grades of any existing sewers, water mains, culverts, and other underground structures adjacent to the property. 6. Contour elevations at two-foot intervals. 7. The layout, names and right-of-way widths of all streets, easements, or tracts of land to be dedicated. 8. The location and sizes of all proposed catch basins, culverts, and other drainage structures. 9. All plat boundary lines measured to the nearest 0.01 of a foot, and bearings and angles based on an accurate field survey. 10. The location of all permanent reference monuments as specified in chapter 4 [of this appendix]. 11. The layout of the proposed improvements, including the following information when applicable: a. Street right-of-way boundaries, names, bearings, angles of intersections, and widths. b. Easement boundaries, bearings, and widths for improvements to be dedicated. 12. The 100-year flood elevation taken from either a FEMA flood insurance map or from an individual study as directed by the building and code enforcement department. CHAPTER 4. - IMPROVEMENT STANDARDS
Section 4.01. - Street layout and design. The location, arrangement, extent, width, and grade of all streets shall conform to this ordinance, and shall be considered in relation to existing and planned streets, topographical conditions, public safety and convenience, and proposed use of land to be served by the streets. The layout of a subdivision shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance and design principles described in this ordinance. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.02. - Conformity. Whenever a tract to be subdivided includes any part of a major arterial, or collector street, such part of said street shall be installed by the subdivider in the location and at the full width indicated by the functional classification for right-of-way and pavement widths indicated in this ordinance. Section 4.03. - Relation to adjoining street system. A. Where appropriate to the subdivision design, proposed streets shall be continuous and in alignment with existing, planned or platted streets with which they are to connect. B. Proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary lines of the tract to be subdivided, unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision with existing and future development of adjacent tracts. C. When there exists adjoining the tract to be subdivided a dedicated or platted half-width street or alley, the other half-width shall be platted. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.04. - Subdivision streets on state highways. Whenever a proposed subdivision has streets that will enter on a state highway maintained and controlled by the Georgia Department of Transportation (GDOT), the preliminary plat shall be submitted by the developer to the GDOT district engineer for approval. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.05. - Restrictions of access. When a tract fronts on a state highway, major arterial, or minor arterial street, the subdivider may be required to have all residential lots to be provided with frontage only upon a collector or local street. Section 4.06. - Access from a single street entrance. A. The design of street access to subdivisions shall comply with all applicable laws and regulations relating to street and intersection design and shall be consistent with accepted engineering standards and practices. B. The maximum number of lots per a single subdivision entrance is 35, unless due to the peculiar shape, or the topography of a tract of land or other unusual condition whereby a variance must be obtained from the city council. The total number of entrances required for a subdivision shall be determined by the city based on the number of lots within the subdivision. C. At its discretion, the city council may require a multi-lane boulevard entrance to a proposed subdivision development consistent with the city's design requirements. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.07. - Street right-of-way widths. Although certain conditions may require additional right-of-way, the minimum width of street right-of-way, measured from lot line to lot line, shall not be less than as follows: 1. Major arterial—100 feet. 2. Minor arterial—80 feet 3. Collector street—80 feet 4. Local street—60 feet with curbs 5. Cut-de-sac—55-foot radius turnaround, residential local streets with curbing. 6. "T" or "Y" turnaround same as required street right-of-way. 7. Mid-block pedestrian way—ten feet. Section 4.08. - Additional width on existing streets. Subdivisions that adjoin existing streets shall dedicate additional right-of-way if needed to meet the minimum street right-of-way requirements in section 4.07. Section 4.09. - Half streets. A. Half streets shall be prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision. B. Where it is determined to be practical to require the dedication of the additional half when adjoining property is subdivided, the other half of the street shall be platted to create a full width right-of-way serving the adjoining tracts of land. Section 4.10. - Pavement widths. The minimum pavement for streets required to be installed at the subdivider's expense are shown below. The city's participation in cost for pavement in excess of the minimum width required, if determined to be necessary by the city engineer, may be negotiated on a case-by-case basis with the city council. _____
*Width from back of curbs **For four-lane highway; if two lane, 28 feet with curbs and 24 feet without curbs Section 4.11. - Speed limits. The posted speed limit on all local streets within a subdivision shall [be] 30 miles per hour. The Manchester Police Department shall determine the speed limit for all other street classifications, subject, as necessary, to approval by GDOT. Section 4.12. - Curbs. Curbs shall be required in all residential subdivisions. Curbs shall be required for streets in commercial and industrial subdivisions. Curbs in all subdivisions shall be L-back curbs 24 inches wide, six inches high, with an 18-inch gutter. All curbs shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete. Curbs shall be designed to provide handicapped access at street intersections, wherever sidewalks are constructed. Section 4.13. - Street grades and elevations. Grades on major and minor arterials shall not exceed five percent and grades on local residential streets shall not exceed 12 percent. The minimum grade on any street shall be one percent. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.14. - Horizontal curves. The radius of horizontal curves on local residential streets within a subdivision shall be no less than 150 feet. The horizontal radius for collector and arterial streets or any streets with a designed speed of more than 25 miles per hour shall comply with AASHTO standards. Section 4.15. - Vertical curves. All changes in grade shall be connected by vertical curves that are as long as conditions permit and under no circumstances should they be shorter than established minimums prescribed by approved highway design methods. Section 4.16. - Centerline sight distance. Minimum street centerline sight distances shall be designed relative to the designated speed of the street and should be measured above the street centerline using a driver-eye height of 3.5 feet and an object height of 4.25 feet. The minimum stopping sight distance for any street shall not be less than 200 feet. _____ Minimum centerline site distances relative to design speed posted on streets are:*
*The minimum stopping distance for streets shall not be less than 200 feet. Sight distance for intersections with minor/major arterials use intersection sight distance measured from a driver's-eye height of 3.5 feet to an object height of 4.25 feet.
*Data taken from AASHTO Guide, A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets. _____ Section 4.17. - Intersection geometries. A. Street intersections shall be as nearly as right angles as possible. In residential subdivisions no intersection shall be at an angle of less than 80 degrees nor more than 100 degrees. B. Street intersection in commercial and industrial subdivisions shall be at an angle of not less than 90 degrees. C. The minimum curb radius at street intersections shall not be less than 20 feet in residential subdivisions. A minimum 25-foot radius shall be required at intersections with existing collector and arterial streets maintained by the city or county. D. The minimum curb radius of street intersections for industrial and commercial subdivisions shall be 50 feet. E. Pedestrian ramps shall be designed for all intersections in accordance with standard drawings for subdivisions and residential developments designed to include sidewalks and shall meet the minimum standards in regards to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The curb shall be depressed to accommodate future installations at the same time as the street. Section 4.18. - Street intersection offset. Street intersections shall have a minimum centerline offset of at least 125 feet. Section 4.19. - Tangents on reverse curves. A tangent of at least 100 feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major and minor arterial streets, or on any street where the posted speed limit will be 35 miles per hour or greater. Section 4.20. - Dead end streets. A. Local streets designed to have one end permanently closed and not connected with any existing street, proposed future street, or not intended to extend to the property line of an adjacent tract, shall be no longer than seven times the lot width provided by the zoning ordinance, unless necessary due to the topographic or other physical conditions of the property. 1. Permanent dead-end streets. Permanent dead-end streets shall be joined by a cul-de-sac with a paved turnaround having an outside diameter of 80 feet (40-foot radius) and a right-of-way of at least 110 feet diameter. Dead-end streets designed to be permanent and that exceed more than 800 feet in length may be required to have a cul-de-sac turn around midway between the entrance intersection and the end of the street to provide maneuvering for emergency vehicles, when the dead-end street is the only street in a subdivision. 2. Temporary dead-end streets. Stub streets that are intended to provide access for future development within a tract of land or adjacent tracts shall be required to have a temporary turnaround area having a diameter of at least 80 feet, consisting of six inches of graded aggregate base. B. For subdivisions with a temporary turnaround, it shall be required of the subdivider to provide a bond or letter of credit equal to the cost of permanent cul-de-sac construction, for a period of two years. Failure of the subdivider to extend the street or to construct a permanent cul-de-sac shall result in the city using the bond or letter of credit funds to complete the cul-de-sac construction. Section 4.21. - Private streets. There shall be no private street platted in any subdivision. Every lot in subdivided property shall be served from and shall have frontage onto a street dedicated to the city; provided, however, when a developer intends to build a "gated community", upon approval of the mayor and council, after review by the city attorney, such private streets may be approved if protective covenants make reasonable provision for maintenance by a mandatory homeowners association. Section 4.22. - Alleys. Alleys may be provided at the rear of lots in residential, commercial, and industrial subdivisions when approved by the community development director. Section 4.23. - General construction requirements. A. Every subdivision developer shall be required to follow the requirements of the soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance, to grade and improve streets, alleys and rights-of-way, to install curbs or ditches when required and to install street name signs in accordance with city specifications. Every subdivider shall be required to comply with the subdivision inspection procedures in chapter 6 [of this appendix]. B. All street design and construction and related material shall be in strict accordance with Georgia Department of Transportation "Standard Specifications, Construction of Roads and Bridges", 1993 Edition, and all revisions thereto and the requirements of sections 4-24 and 4-25. Where circumstances dictate variations from the standard specifications upon recommendation of the city engineer, the city council may vary the requirements, provided the design of materials accepted are in all ways commensurate with good practice. C. All materials, equipment, labor and other matters related to street construction shall be provided by the developer. The following is a summary of the improvements required: 1. Grading. All streets, roads, and alleys shall be graded to their full width right-of-way by the subdivider so that the pavements and sidewalks, when installed in the future, can be constructed on the same level plane. The preparation of the right-of-way before grading is started and the construction of cuts and fills shall be accomplished according to the specifications of the city. All stumps, tree limbs, and other organic material shall be removed from the rights-of-way and building site areas and disposed of in accordance with law in a permitted landfill. No stumps, limbs or other organic material, including building debris, scrap lumber, etc., shall be buried anywhere in the subdivision development. In developments over ten acres, the city manager may issue a permit authorizing burning, using approved pit burners; provided all other state and local regulatory permits are first obtained and the city is not under a burn warning or hazardous air conditions alert. 2. [Profile.] Three copies of an as-built subgrade centerline profile shall be submitted. The profile shall include both proposed and as-built centerline elevations at every even station. No curb and gutter or waterlines shall be installed prior to subgrade approval. 3. Storm damage. An adequate drainage system, including necessary curb, pipes, culverts, headwalls, intersectional drains, drop inlets, bridges, swale ditches, and detention areas, shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water and prepared by a registered professional engineer or landscape architect. 4. Roadway surfacing. After preparation of the subgrade the roadbed shall have base material and paving applied according to city specifications. Section 4.24. - Construction requirements for residential subdivisions streets. A. The design and construction requirements for residential subdivisions shall comply with the minimum standards shown in table 4-1. B. The grading, base and pavement for residential street construction shall be as follows: 1. Grading. All streets shall be graded to the elevations shown on the approved construction plans. a. Clearing and grubbing. After the development permit has been issued, a preconstruction conference has been held, the city engineer duly notified, and all required silt and erosion control measures installed and approved, the contractor may begin clearing and grubbing the project. All trees, stumps, logs, roots, grass, weeds, poles, and other objectionable matter shall be cleared and grubbed from within the construction limits of the project. A 30-foot undisturbed buffer shall be maintained on all property lines prior to submission of construction improvements plans. No rubbish or other material resulting from the clearing and grubbing of the roadway may be buried within the construction limits of the roadway or detention ponds. If burning is permitted, all burn pits must be located outside of the roadway construction limits. b. Excavation. All grading operations shall be planned and executed by the contractor in such a manner as to provide suitable subgrade material in the top 12 inches of the roadway. In areas where the material in place is not suitable for subgrades, these areas shall be undercut a minimum of 12 inches and backfilled with suitable material. All rock and boulders in the roadbed shall be excavated to a depth of at least 12 inches below the subgrade and the space backfilled to the correct grade with suitable material. Any stones, broken rock, or boulders resulting from the grading of the roadway may not be placed in any roadway fill area except when approved by the development inspector and then under his supervision. During the construction of the roadway on a day to day basis, the roadbed edges shall be kept lower than the center and the grading shall be done so that the surfaces of the excavated areas and fill will be kept reasonably smooth and well drained. Adequate surface ditches shall be cut at the tops of cut slopes, extending to each end of the cuts in order to carry the water from the side hill. Side ditches or gutters emptying from cuts to fill areas shall be turned outward so as to prevent erosion of the fill slopes. c. Placement of fill. Fill construction shall not begin until all clearing and grubbing of the fill area has been completed. All depressions in the ground shall be filled level with the adjacent surface using suitable material and compacted to the approximate density of the surrounding soil before placement of the fill is begun. The entire area upon which fill is to be placed shall be plowed, scarified, and finely broken up to a depth of a minimum of six inches. Before the placement of fill material is begun, all loosened soil shall be compacted the approximate density of the underlying soil. Where a depth of fill and surfacing is three feet or less, the original ground shall be compacted the approximate density of the underlying soil. Where a depth of fill and surfacing is three feet or less, the original ground shall be compacted a minimum 12 inches deep to at least 95 percent of the maximum laboratory dry density as determined from representative samples of the material being compacted. In areas where layers of organic or other unstable materials exists, the existing ground shall be excavated, for the full width of the fill area, to an underlying stable material. The subgrade thus created shall then be compacted to the approximate density of the underlying material. All fill material shall be deposited and spread in uniform horizontal layers, not more than six inches thick, for the full width of the fill area, and these layers shall be kept uniform by the use of graders, bulldozers or other approved equipment. Each layer shall be compacted within the range of optimum moisture content necessary to achieve the compaction required. Material containing too much water shall be dried to the correct moisture content. If the material is too dry, water shall be added and uniformly mixed with the soil before it is compacted. Fills shall be compacted to at least 95 percent of the maximum dry density to within the top 12 inches of the fill. The top 12 inches of the fill shall be compacted to at least 100 percent of the maximum dry density. The entire roadbed shall be scarified and compacted with a sheep's foot or other approved rollers. While the work is in progress, [the] contractor shall maintain the surface in a manner so that the excavation, fills, subgrade, base course, and ditches always present a smooth and even surface. d. [Equipment on site]. The contractor shall have available on the job at all times at least one motor patrol grader with adequate power to blade and maintain the roadbed. Suitable scarifiers shall also be available for use whenever necessary. e. Final finishing of roadway. After all excavation has been completed and all fills have been placed, the entire road bed surface shall be finally shaped with a grading machine supplemented with hand work whenever required, to secure a smooth surface and uniform cross-section. Slopes of cuts and fills shall also be carefully shaped to the true section specified. When final shaping is finished, the road surface shall conform accurately to the line, grade and cross section shown of plans, and no roots, sod, grass, stones, or other unsuitable material shall remain in the top 12 inches of the finished road bed. All ditches and drains shall be opened to effectively drain the roadway. 2. Placement of curb and gutter. After sanitary sewer and water lines have been installed, all storm drainage in place, and the final finishing of the roadway has been approved by the city engineer, the installation of the concrete curb and gutter may begin. All concrete curb and gutter shall be in accordance with Manchester construction standards. Any curb and gutter which does not conform to a true section, texture, line and grade shall be removed and replaced as directed by the development inspector. 3. Subgrade. Before placing any pavement base the entire surface of the subgrade shall be plowed, harrowed, and mixed to a depth of at least six inches. If a subgrade stabilization material is required it shall be incorporated into the subgrade at this time. After the material has been thoroughly mixed the subgrade shall be brought into a proper line and grade and compacted to 100 percent of maximum dry density just prior to placing the base material. The centerline profile shall conform to the established elevations with an acceptable tolerance of one-half inch. The acceptance crown tolerance shall be one-half inch. 4. Base construction. The city engineer shall be notified 24 hours prior to the placing of any of the base material. After the inspector is satisfied all the equipment necessary for the proper construction of road base is on the proper line, grade, and crown, and compacted to the required density, he may authorize the placing of the base material. After the base material has been placed and compacted to the required density the city engineer will check the completed base course. All areas found to be deficient shall be marked and corrected before any asphalt pavement is placed. Areas where the crown is found to exceed that which is specified or the exposed edge of the concrete gutter is less than the minimum depth required, shall be reshaped and rolled to obtain the required cross-section. After the compacted material has been approved, cores shall be taken as directed by the development inspector to determine the thickness of the constructed base course. Areas found to be deficient in thickness shall be corrected as directed by the development inspector. A copy of all delivery tickets for the graded aggregate base material shall be furnished prior to the placing [of] any asphaltic concrete paving material. A shortage in the base material used shall require that the asphaltic concrete surface course thickness be increased. All work and materials shall be in accordance with the pertinent Graded Aggregate Construction sections of the Georgia Department of Transportation "Standard Specifications..." latest edition. 5. Paving. After the road base has been accepted by the development inspector and upon his approval the contractor shall begin the construction of the asphaltic concrete pavement. All asphaltic concrete material and construction shall be in accordance with the Hot Mix Asphaltic Concrete Construction sections of the Georgia Department of Transportation "Standard Specifications..." latest edition. After the material has been placed and rolled to the satisfaction of the inspector he shall check the cross section of the finished pavement. Any area found to be deficient shall be marked and a record of deficiencies made by the development inspector. 6. [ Overlay. ] If, in the opinion of the city engineer, the extent of deficiencies will impair the performance of the pavement, he shall direct that an overlay of a minimum thickness of one inch be placed before the roadway is opened to traffic. A copy of the delivery tickets for the asphaltic concrete material used shall be furnished to the development inspector at the time of completion of the work. If the delivery tickets indicate a shortage in the material used from the quantity estimated the development inspector may require a minimum one inch overlay of the streets. 7. [ Core tests. ] Upon acceptance of the surface course by the city engineer, the developer shall have core tests made as directed by the city, to verify the thickness of the street base and asphalt pavement. If these indicate a deficiency in thickness of the street base and asphalt pavement an overlay shall be required when the following deficiencies occur: a. When the number of cores deficient in thickness with the allowable one-quarter of an inch tolerance exceeds 35 percent of the total cores taken on one street. b. When two or more consecutive tests show a deficiency of more than one-quarter of an inch allowable tolerance. When a core shows a deficiency in excess of the allowable tolerance additional cores will be taken to delineate the area of the deficient thickness. c. Any required overlay shall extend a minimum of 150 feet beyond the outer limits of the deficient area for the full width of the street. Smooth, neat joints shall be saw cut normal to the roadway for full depth of asphalt pavement, removing the original pavement overlay. The thickness of the overlay shall be determined by the depth of the deficient area and shall not be less than one inch in compacted thickness. The type of material used in the overlay shall be specified by the county. d. After the paving has been inspected and approved, the pavement edges or behind the curb and gutter shall be backfilled and compacted and the ditches and back slopes properly graded, shaped, seeded and mulched. An 80 percent stand of grass must be obtained. All swales and ditches excavated below required depth shall be backfilled and compacted to 95 percent of maximum dry density. _____ TABLE 4-1 RESIDENTIAL SUBDIVISION STREET DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS
TABLE 4-2 INDUSTRIAL, COMMERCIAL/OFFICE SUBDIVISIONS AND ARTERIAL ROADS
_____ Section 4.25. - Construction requirements for industrial and commercial subdivision streets and arterial roads. A. The design and construction requirements for subdivision developments for industrial, commercial, or office use and streets which are to be city or county arterial roads shall comply with the minimum standards shown on table 4-2, industrial and commercial subdivision streets and arterial roads. Arterial roads shall be required to have concrete curb and gutter along each side in accordance with Manchester construction standards. B. All grading, subgrade, base and pavement for industrial commercial and arterial street construction shall be in accordance with section 4-24 and table 4-2. Section 4.26. - Improvement to existing streets and rights-of-way. Every subdivision shall have frontage on a paved city or county road. The existing roads upon which the subdivision has frontage and access shall be widened, resurfaced, or paved to city or county specifications for the full length of the frontage of the subdivision if found necessary due to the existing road being deficient relative to city or county specifications. 1. Existing unpaved road. Any unpaved road upon which a subdivision has frontage and access shall be paved and widened, according to the functional class of the road along the frontage of the subdivision to the nearest intersection with a paved road. The minimum right-of-way required according to section 4-07 shall be dedicated along the entire frontage of the subdivision. 2. Existing paved road. Any existing paved city or county road upon which a subdivision has frontage and access and which is deficient relative to city or county specifications shall be resurfaced and widened for the entire frontage of the subdivision. The minimum right-of-way required according to section 4-07 shall be dedicated along the entire frontage of the subdivision. Section 4.27. - Subdivision access control. A. Any subdivision that has an entrance onto a state highway, major arterial, minor arterial, or collector road shall provide lanes for acceleration/deceleration, ingress and egress. B. Acceleration and deceleration lanes. Acceleration/deceleration lanes are required at all entrances to subdivisions and industrial or commercial developments. Acceleration/deceleration lanes shall be 12 feet in width plus curb and gutter for a minimum distance of 150 feet with a 75-foot taper for the acceleration lane. Intersection radius must be 20 feet to 30 feet. Section 4.28. - Marginal access streets. Where a subdivision abuts or includes a major arterial street, marginal access streets may be required to be parallel to and on each side of the major arterial right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the use of the intervening lands for landscaped buffer areas. This design is intended to provide protection for residential properties from local residential traffic. See section 4.24 for alternative design treatment of lots abutting major arterial streets. Section 4.29. - Street names. A. Proposed streets that are obviously in alignment with other already existing and named streets, shall bear the names of the streets in which they are in alignment with. The names of proposed streets shall not duplicate existing street names, irrespective of the use of the word street, avenue, boulevard, drive, place, court, etc. in the naming of the street. B. All proposed street names for new roads or roads within commercial, industrial or residential subdivisions must be approved by the city manager during the preliminary plat review process or prior to recording the final plat. Any request to change the name of an existing road must be approved by the city council. Section 4.30. - Street signs. The public works department shall determine the need and location of street signs within a subdivision. The location of the street signs shall be determined during the review of the preliminary plat. The standard steel street posts or wooden four-inch by four-inch post with horizontal reflectorized street name plates with four-inch letters shall be furnished and installed by the subdivider. Section 4.31. - Traffic signs. The public works department shall determine the need and location of traffic signs and street markings within a subdivision during the review of the preliminary plat. Traffic signs shall be furnished and installed by the subdivider in accordance with the U.S. Department of Transportation's Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, latest edition. Cross reference— Signs, ch. 58; traffic and vehicles, ch. 74. Section 4.32. - House numbers. House numbers for subdivision lots shall be assigned by the Manchester Postmaster prior to the approval of the final plat. Section 4.33. - Subdivision point of entry signs. Signs that are erected on the ground to identify the name and entrance of a residential, commercial or industrial subdivision shall be permitted, provided they are not located and constructed in a manner that creates a traffic hazard. The size and construction of point of entry signs shall comply with the sign ordinance. Section 4.34. - Street lighting. The city council will not accept the streets of a subdivision unless the lighting requirements as set forth in this section are met by the developer. A. All lighting that is to be a part of the City of Manchester will be high pressure sodium. B. Lighting applications: 1. Residential overhead. Cobra head fixtures to be mounted on existing poles. Fixtures to be supplied by the power company. Bulbs to be 100 or 150 watt high pressure sodium. 2. Residential underground. Decorative post top poles and fixtures unless otherwise specified by the City of Manchester. Poles and fixtures to be supplied by the power company. Bulbs to be 100 or 150 watt high pressure sodium. Twenty-foot poles with a 16-foot mounting height. 3. Commercial and industrial overhead. Cobra head fixtures to be supplied by the power company. Bulbs to be 250 or 400 watt high pressure sodium. 4. Commercial and industrial undergrounds. Cobra head fixtures to be mounted on steel poles with minimum mounting height of 30 feet. Poles and fixtures to be supplied by the power company. Bulbs of 250 watt high pressure sodium to be spaced 275 feet apart. Bulbs of 400 watt high pressure sodium to be spaced 325 feet apart. C. Cut-off fixtures will not be accepted due to the additional number of fixtures needed to light a given distance. D. Spacing of fixtures in subdivisions will be determined by the public works department to provide uniform lighting of roadway. Lights are placed in each cul-de-sac and at the intersection of roadways. Trenching fees charged by the power companies are paid by the homeowners of the subdivision or the developer petitioning for lights. E. After installation of lights, lights will not be removed unless deemed necessary by the city. Additional lights may be requested by homeowners with written approval of the adjacent homeowners effected by the fixtures. F. Spacing for lighting in subdivisions: 1. Overhead fixtures. Three hundred to 325 feet between fixtures, as allowed by transfer locations. 2. Underground fixtures. Minimum of 150 feet, maximum of 210 feet between fixtures. G. All fixtures are to be installed as to provide an adequate clear zone from back of curb. H. When 50 percent of the lots of a subdivision have been built upon, the developer may petition the city council for acceptance of the subdivision's street lights as an addition to the city's street light system. Section 4.35. - Street surface drainage specifications. The size, length, and location of all surface drainage pipes or structures shall be shown on all preliminary plats. All storm drain pipes or culverts carrying storm water from the street and adjacent property or through lots in the subdivision shall be extended to at least 30 feet behind the rear of the structure to be located on the lot. Storm water shall be released into a channel or swale without causing scouring, erosion, or resulting in sedimentation of the receiving channel. The outlet channel shall include structural and vegetative measures to assure non-erosive velocities of storm water. All outlet channels should be within drainage easements of sufficient width as shown on the final plat. 1. Installations, backfilling, and compaction around drainage pipes shall be in accordance with GDOT specifications. All pipes shall have a minimum cover of 18 inches from the bottom of the road base, and head walls or inlet basins constructed at the ends of the pipes. 2. All cross drain pipes within public rights-of-way for the purpose of providing storm drainage shall be coated metal pipe, concrete, or other material approved by the county. Ninety-five percent compaction shall be required around all pipes. 3. The design of drainage structures shall be based on recognized hydrological formula. 4. Piped collection systems for public streets (catch basins, inlets, cross drains, longitudinal piping), shall be designed for the 50-year storm. 5. Road culverts, which carry live streams, and off site drainage, shall be designed for the 100-year storm. Section 4.36. - Storm drainage detention structures on site. The city may require on-site storm drainage and detention facilities for any subdivision, or commercial or industrial development project. The rate of run-off from any development shall not exceed the rate that existed prior to the development. On-site detention facilities shall be constructed for a 100-year storm, and may include permanent retention basins, underground storage of storm water, roof system retention, parking lot design for controlled release of storm water, or other structures approved by the city engineer. Plans for storm water detention facilities shall be accompanied with storm water runoff calculations based on recognized formulas, and shall conform to the requirements of generally accepted engineers practice. Section 4.37. - Blocks. A. Layout. Subdivision blocks shall have sufficient width, to provide for two tiers of lots of appropriate depth and length. The length, widths, and shapes of blocks shall be determined with regard to: 1. Zoning requirements for lot sized and dimensions; 2. Provision of adequate building sites suitable to special needs of the type of use contemplated; 3. Convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic; and, 4. Topographic condition. B. Length. Blocks shall be neither less than 500 feet nor more than 1,200 feet in length, except where topographic or other conditions of the site make such dimensions impractical. C. Mid-block pedestrian easements. For blocks over 800 feet in length, the city may require one or more public crosswalks of not less than ten feet wide near the center and entirely across the full width of the block, when necessary for access to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, transportation and other community facilities. D. Width. Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two tiers of lots with adequate depth relative to the width of lots, except where fronting a major or minor arterial road, or prevented by topographic conditions, or by the size and shape of the property. Section 4.38. - Lots. Generally, the size, shape, width, depth, orientation, and minimum building setbacks, including the front, side and rear yard lines of lots shall be in accordance with the zoning ordinance. 1. Side lot lines. Insofar as practical, side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight lines or radial to curved street right-of-way lines. Side lot lines shall be in line with cross drain pipes under streets where they are located. 2. Frontage on public street. Each lot in a subdivision shall front upon a public street or road that is not less than 50 feet in right-of-way width. Each lot must have at least 30 feet of frontage at the property line. 3. Lots on cul-de-sac. Any lot which has frontage on a cul-de-sac turnaround shall have at least 30 feet of frontage at the front property lines, shall have a minimum lot front yard building line setback required by the zoning ordinance and the side yard requirements. 4. Corner lots. Corner lots for residential use shall have an extra width of at least 15 feet more than required by the zoning ordinance for interior lots in a block in order to permit the appropriate building setback from and orientation of both streets upon which the lot has frontage. 5. Through lots. Through lots or double frontage lots shall be prohibited except where essential to provide separation of residential development from major traffic arterials or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation of the property to be subdivided. Where necessary, a bermed, landscaped planting easement of at least 15 feet in width and four to six feet in height shall be provided across the frontage along the major traffic artery for which there can be no ingress or egress for the affected lots. 6. Flag lots. Flag lots shall be prohibited in subdivisions unless topographic conditions, or the shape and orientation of the property to be subdivided make the inclusion of some flag lots necessary. Flag lots must provide minimum frontage requirements as stated in the zoning ordinance and are not intended to provide access to other properties so as to circumvent the street and right-of-way requirements of the zoning ordinance. Flag lots are intended only to provide use of the rear portion of the extremely deep tracts of land for residential purposes. 7. Large tracts or parcels. When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of future streets and logical further subdivision. 8. Minimum lot size and public facilities. The subdivider shall connect with public sewer and water facilities to each lot in the development. Section 4.39. - Easements and widths. A. [ Easements.] All lots within a subdivision shall provide easements for stormwater drainage and detention systems, sanitary sewers, and, for gas, electric, and telephone utilities. B. Rear lot line easements. Easements along all rear lot lines shall be a minimum of 20 feet wide. Ten feet shall be provided on the final plat from each adjoining lot. Wider easements may be required depending on the size, location, and depth of proposed or existing sewers. C. Side lot easements. Easements along side lot lines shall be a minimum of 20 feet wide, ten feet along each adjoining lot. Wider easements may be required depending on the size and depth of proposed or existing sewers. D. Easements along streams and drainage ways. Where a watercourse, drainage way, channel or stream traverses a subdivision, there shall be provided a storm water drainage easement or drainage right-of-way along each side of the watercourse for the purpose of widening, deepening, relocating, improving, or protecting such easement. The easement shall not be less than 25 feet wide. A wider easement may be required for large streams and drainage ways. The easement shall extend from the top of the stream bank at least 12.5 feet away from the stream. (Note: State law prohibits any land-disturbing activity within 24 horizontal feet from the banks of any state waters, as measured from the point where vegetation has been wrested by normal stream flow or wave action.) E. Minimum lot area and easements. Proposed subdivision lots that are traversed by utility easements for gas, electric, telephone, and water and sewer utilities shall contain the minimum buildable area defined by the zoning district, exclusive of outside of areas occupied by these easements. F. Stormwater detention facility easements. All stormwater detention facilities shall be accessible from a public street by a minimum 20-foot wide easement and there shall be an easement for the detention facility including a minimum of 20 feet around the outside perimeter of the facility. Section 4.40. - Permanent reference monuments. Materials, size and location: A. Concrete cylinders or rectangular prisms not less than four inches in diameter or square and 42 inches in length shall be set at the extreme corners of subdivisions. B. Steel pins not less than one-half inch in diameter and 20 inches long shall be set at the following locations: 1. All points where street lines intersect the boundary lines. 2. All angle points and points of curve on each street. 3. All lot corners. C. Resetting monuments. Any monuments disturbed by construction or grading shall be reset. Section 4.41. - Water distribution systems. A. Generally. Water mains properly connected with the city water supply system or with an alternate supply system approved by the city council shall be constructed in such a manner so as to adequately serve all lots shown on the subdivision plat for both residential use and fire protection. All materials, labor, equipment, and other items related to construction of the water distribution system shall be provided in accordance to city specifications. B. Extension without subdivisions. The subdivider shall be responsible for the material and labor cost of extending the water systems within the subdivision as directed and inspected by the water and sewer department. 1. The extensions of water mains within the subdivision shall be designed to provide adequate hydraulic capacity for future extensions to the surrounding area and must be connected to existing surrounding water mains to accomplish desirable hydraulic looping. 2. Dead-end mains within a subdivision shall be avoided where practical, as determined by the water and sewer department. Water mains in dead-end streets shall have a fire hydrant installed at the end of the line on a common lot corner. C. Minimum pipe diameter. Typically, the minimum water main pipe diameter within a subdivision shall be six inches. The need for smaller or larger sized mains shall be determined by the water and sewer department, to assure adequate water supply and fire protection to the subdivision, and to assure adequate water flow for future development in the area. D. Installation. All service lines shall be installed by the developer's contractor according to the water and sewer department's standard detail. E. Valves. Valves shall be installed to effect a minimum cut-off of mains in cases of emergency shutdown as determined by the water and sewerage department. F. Fire hydrants. Fire hydrants will be installed so that all residential property within a subdivision will be less than 300 feet from a fire hydrant, with a maximum spacing of 525 feet between hydrants. G. City design of water mains. The water and sewer department and the Georgia Environmental Protection Division shall approve the design and materials of water mains, and all materials, fittings, and accessories for public water systems in a subdivision. H. Location and depth of water mains. All water mains shall be located at least four feet below finished grade and shall be eight feet in back of the curb line or seven feet from the edge of pavement and within the public street right-of-way. I. Fire flow requirements: 1. The minimum fire flow and residual pressure for single family detached houses or duplexes shall be 750 gallons per minute (g.p.m) at 20 pounds per square inch (p.s.i.) residual pressure as required by the state fire marshal. 2. The minimum fire flow for all other types of development shall be determined on a case-by-case basis by the water and sewer department. 3. Hydrostatic testing. The water and sewer department shall authorize hydrostatic testing of water mains and hydrants in a subdivision. Leakage testing shall be two hours at 1½ times the system operating pressure. Section 4.42. - Sanitary sewer system. A. Generally. Sanitary sewers shall be installed to serve all lots with connection to the public system. Prior to the submittal of construction plans, the location, size, plans and specifications of the sanitary sewer system shall be approved by appropriate city officials, and the Georgia Environmental Protection Division as required. B. Minimum sewer pipe diameter. All sewer lines within a subdivision shall be at least eight inches in diameter. Larger diameter lines may be required by the water and sewer department where necessary to provide adequate capacity for anticipated development in the immediate area of the subdivision, or to serve the requirements of certain uses within industrial or commercial office subdivision, or within a planned unit development project. C. Sanitary sewer collection system. Lateral sanitary sewer lines within a subdivision shall include a minimum of four-inch diameter sewer service connection installed for each lot. The service connection shall be extended to the right-of-way and clearly marked with the clean out extended four feet above finished grade and capped until the lot is developed. D. Construction drawings. Construction drawings for the sewer system within a subdivision shall be submitted to the water and sewer department and the city engineer for approval. All construction shall be done in accordance with design specifications of the water and sewer department and the city engineer. E. [Certification of drawings.] A professional engineer registered in the State of Georgia shall certify construction drawings. F. Design. A professional engineer registered in the State of Georgia shall design the proposed sewer system. The following specifications shall apply: 1. Sewer pipe shall be PVC or ductile iron pipe as per standards and specifications of the water and sewer department. 2. The minimum sewer pipe size shall be eight inches for mains and minimum four inches for stub outs. Minimum slope. All sewers shall be designed to give mean velocities when flowing full of not less than 2.7 feet per second. All velocity and flow calculations shall be based on the Manning Formula using an N value of 0.013. Exceptions to these minimum slopes shall be made at the upper end of lateral sewers serving under 30 houses. The sewer shall have a minimum slope of 0.70 percent. Where lateral sewers served less than ten houses, the minimum slope shall not be less than one percent. Minimum Slopes for Sewer Size Indicated
3. Ductile iron pipe shall be used as follows: a. Where the sewer line crosses drainage structures or open streams; b. For the influent joint of pipe at all drop manholes; c. For outfall sewers at depths less than four feet; and greater than 16 feet; d. For stub-outs at depths of less than five feet. 4. Sewer lines shall be located along the centerline of the street wherever possible. Wherever sewer lines are located outside the centerline of the street, a minimum 20-foot sanitary sewer easement will be required, with the easement following the centerline of the sewer and designated clearly on the final plat. 5. The minimum depth for sewers located in street shall be seven feet for mains and five feet for stub-outs, or as determined by the water and sewer department. 6. Manholes shall be located not further than 400 feet apart. Manholes shall be constructed at all turns and grade changes. 7. Sewer lines shall be located within a minimum 20-foot easement when not located within a public right-of-way, as provided in subsection F.4. of this section. The water and sewer department may require wider easements depending upon the depth and size of the sewer line. 8. The water and sewer department reserves the right to revise the design [of] any and all sewer lines, and related materials, accessories, and fittings within a subdivision. 9. Where required. Where it is anticipated that the water and sewer department will extend a trunk or interceptor sewer line adjacent to the subdivision, sewer service lines shall be installed within the subdivision and temporarily plugged or capped at the points of service connection in the proposed lateral or trunk sewer line at individual lot lines in accordance with the water and sewer department specifications. Section 4.43. - Sidewalks. A. Generally. Sidewalks shall be constructed within a single-family residential subdivisions on both sides of all streets within the public right-of-way. B. Construction specifications. Sidewalks shall be four feet in width and four inches in thickness and shall be constructed of Portland cement concrete. Sidewalks shall be installed no closer than two feet to the back of curb line and shall not be constructed over any underground gas, electric, communications, or water and sewer utilities. Sidewalks and curbs, at street intersections, shall be designed to permit handicapped access (see construction standard detail for location of sidewalks). C. Installation. Typically, sidewalks shall be installed by the builder before the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. However, all sidewalks are required to be complete throughout the subdivision (by the developer) before the end of the two-year maintenance period. Broken curbing and sidewalk after this two-year period will be repaired by the builder before the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 66. Section 4.44. - Gas, electric and telecommunications utilities. A. Responsibility. The subdivider shall make the necessary arrangements with the Manchester Gas Department, Georgia Power Department, and other appropriate utility companies for the installation of utilities to assure that all lots have adequate gas, electrical and telecommunication services, including cable television. B. Enforcement. The building and code enforcement department shall not issue any occupancy permits for structures in a subdivision or development until all necessary utilities have been installed. C. Exemptions. The following specific facilities shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter: 1. Poles used exclusively for street lighting. 2. Poles, overhead lines, and associated overhead structures owned by a utility company crossing over any portion of an area from which overhead wires are allowed. 3. Overhead lines attached to the exterior of a building by means of a bracket or similar device and extending from one location on the building, or to an adjacent building without crossing any street or right-of-way. 4. Radio antennae and associated structures and equipment used for furnishing communications service. 5. Service terminals and necessary pad-mounted electric transformer equipment installed above ground, used to distribute communications service. D. Electrical transformer substations and lift stations. Transformer substations and sewer lift stations may be required within subdivision developments to serve the proposed developments and a larger area. These facilities shall be fenced with a chain link security fence and shall be landscaped with tree plantings and shrubs. The utility company shall obtain an easement for these installations that shall be clearly indicated on the final plat. Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 78. Section 4.45. - Cemeteries and grave sites. Prior to development, where a site contains, or borders a cemetery or grave site, the developer shall clearly delineate the area on all site plans and construction drawings. The site shall be enclosed or fenced with a temporary fence or equivalent that allows access but clearly marks the site for protection during construction. In addition, a permanent ten-foot natural or landscaped buffer shall be maintained around the site and shown on the final plat. The site shall also be visibly marked before grading is to begin. Cross reference— Cemeteries, ch. 26. CHAPTER 5. - PUBLIC DEDICATION AND RESERVATION
Section 5.01. - Public sites; generally. Where a site within a tract of land proposed for subdivision is determined to be necessary for a public park, school, fire station, water or sewage treatment plant, water reservoir, public works yard, or other public facility, the necessary land area shall be reserved or dedicated to the appropriate public authority having jurisdiction over the operation and maintenance of the proposed facility. The final plat for the subdivision shall show these sites as being reserved or dedicated. Section 5.02. - Dedication. When a site is dedicated by a subdivider for public purposes to the appropriate authority, the land shall be transferred by a deed and dedication plat and recorded by the clerk of superior court, following acceptance: 1. Park and recreation sites shall be first recommended by the planning and zoning board prior to action for acceptance of dedication of the site by the city council. 2. The board of education shall review the location and need for the school sites, and decide whether or not to accept dedication of a site within 90 days of receipt of a preliminary plan. The board of education shall consult with the planning and zoning board for recommendation on school sites. If the board of education decides to accept dedication of the site for a school, it shall notify the city council. The city council shall then direct the city manager to have the deed and dedication plat recorded by the clerk of superior court. 3. Land dedication for fire or police stations, public buildings, rights-of-way, and other public works shall be transferred by the subdivider to the city by a deed and dedication plat and recorded by the clerk of superior court, following acceptance by the city council. 4. Land dedicated for streets, water and sewage easements, drainage easements and other facilities under jurisdiction of the city shall be recorded following acceptance of the city council. Section 5.03. - Reservation. A. When a site is determined necessary for public purposes by the appropriate authorities, and the subdivider elects to reserve rather than dedicate the site, then it shall be reserved for public purposes. The subdivider shall allow a period of two years from the date of preliminary plat and construction improvements plan approval, during which time the appropriate city authorities may authorize and complete the purchase of the site. B. During the two-year period for which the appropriate authorities have to acquire the reserved site for public purposes, the subdivider may proceed with the necessary approvals, for subdivision of the remainder of the development of the reserved tract. CHAPTER 6. - SUBDIVISION CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION
Section 6.01. - Preconstruction review and approval. A. All subdivisions and development projects shall construct and install all improvements in accordance with the requirements of chapter 4 [of this appendix]. The steps for preconstruction review and approval and required inspections shall be followed as indicated below. B. Prior to beginning development of the subdivision the subdivider shall first obtain the following approvals: 1. Preliminary plan approval required. The subdivider must first have a preliminary subdivision plan approved by the city. 2. Soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. The subdivider must have a soil erosion and sedimentation control plan in compliance with the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Plan. The plan shall be reviewed by the natural resources conservation district. No development permit shall be issued for any development that does not have an approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. 3. Preconstruction conference. Prior to the issuing of a development permit, the city engineer shall contact the developer for a preconstruction conference. The preconstruction conference shall include a review of the soil erosion and sedimentation control plan, street cross sections and profiles, construction specifications, procedures for inspections and testing, storm water drainage and detention facilities, water/sewer service, and any other matters concerning the development. The subdivider shall provide a list of names, telephone numbers, addresses, and business license numbers of all contractors and subcontractors employed on a job. 4. Development permit required. The building and code enforcement department shall issue a development permit only after the approval of the construction improvements plans and soil erosion and sedimentation control plan. Site grading shall be limited only to those areas clearly defined on the approved plans. Any site grading which is done without an approved soil erosion control plan and development permit is a violation of this chapter and shall result in enforcement penalties as provided by chapter 8 [of this appendix]. Instances where grading has occurred prior to issuance of a development permit, or when grading has exceeded the area approved according to the approved plans and development permit, the permit fee amount shall be doubled. Any violations of the conditions or limitations imposed by the development permit shall also be subject to penalties provided by chapter 8 [of this appendix]. Section 6.02. - Inspection procedures. The subdivider is responsible for making requests for inspections before beginning any of the stages indicated below. No grading shall commence without an approved soil erosion and sedimentation control plan and a development permit. Soil erosion prevention measures shall be installed prior to grading as required by the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance. 1. Inspection notification. The subdivider shall notify the building and code enforcement department at least 24 hours before any stage of construction begins. If construction during any phase is stopped or delayed due to inclement weather or other reasons, the subdivider shall notify the building and code enforcement department 24 hours before commencing construction activity again. 2. Clearing and grubbing. After providing the required notice to the building and code enforcement department, clearing of the right-of-way may begin. All work is to be in accordance with section 4.24 of this ordinance. 3. Street grading. Following inspection and approval of the street clearing and grubbing by the development inspector, and street grade stakes have been set by the project's engineer, the contractor may proceed with the grading of the streets. All work is to be in accordance with section 4.24. Compaction tests shall be made as required by the city engineer to determine that the required 95 percent maximum dry density is being achieved. At least one test shall be made over each storm drain pipe when it has been covered with 18 inches of backfill material. 4. Subgrade compaction. Following the completion and approval of the street grading and installation of curb and gutter the contractor may proceed with the preparation of the subgrade in accordance with section 4.24. Compaction tests shall be made at the direction of the city engineer to determine that the required 100 percent maximum dry density is being achieved. 5. Curb and gutter. Following the installation of all proposed sanitary sewer and water lines and acceptance of the street grading the contractor may proceed with the construction of the curb and gutter. All work and materials shall be in accordance with section 4.24. 6. Base preparation. After the street subgrade has been inspected and approved, the contractor may proceed with the construction of the street pavement base. All work and materials shall be in accordance with section 4.24 and table 4-1 or table 4-2. Compaction tests shall be made as directed by the city to assure that the required 100 percent maximum dry density has been achieved. Cores shall be taken as directed by the city to determine the constructed thickness of the base course. 7. Paving. After the road base has been approved and accepted by the development inspector, the contractor may proceed with the construction of the asphaltic concrete binder and/or surface courses. All work and materials shall be in accordance with section 4.24 and table 4-1 and table 4-2 of this ordinance. Compaction tests shall be made as directed by the city to assure that the required 98 percent maximum has been achieved. 8. Street core tests. Street core test results shall be submitted to the building and code enforcement department prior to the recording of a final subdivision plat. These cores shall be taken as directed by the development inspector immediately upon completion of the surface course. Refer to section 4.24. 9. Soil erosion and sedimentation control. During all of the stages of inspection, soil erosion, and sedimentation control measures shall be inspected. The subdivision shall be subject to soil erosion and sedimentation control inspection at any other times determined necessary to assure compliance with the approved plan. The subdivider is responsible for continued maintenance of all soil erosion and sedimentation control measures as required by the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance. 10. Work stoppage. A stop work order may be issued at anytime if it is determined to be necessary due to failure of the subdivider to comply with any of the requirements of this ordinance, the zoning ordinance or, the soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinance. A stop work notice shall be posted on the site and the subdivider shall be notified in writing concerning the reasons for the stop work order. Any work that proceeds in violation of a stop order shall subject the subdivider to penalties as prescribed in section 8.03 of this ordinance. 11. Work delays. If construction during any phase of development is delayed due to inclement weather or for other reasons, the subdivider shall notify the building and code enforcement department prior to resuming construction activities. Section 6.03. - Minimum inspection requirements. The following inspections shall be made and documented by the city: 1. Street improvement: a. Check results of subgrade, base, and embankment compaction tests. b. Test rolling of the finished subgrade and base course shall be accomplished using a three axle tandem-axle truck with a minimum gross weight of 15 tons. Rolling shall be performed as directed by the city engineer. c. Inspect for compaction around all drainage pipes and drainage structures. d. Inspect and document the alignment and condition of curb and gutter. e. Check fill material before authorizing use. f. Inspect and document the placement of asphalt pavement. Check core testing results. g. Obtain from the subdivider all records of asphalt mix and materials quantities. h. Require as-graded street profiles and review for compliance to the approved construction plans prior to installing any curb and gutter or base material. 2. Storm drainage improvements: a. Inspect cross drain pipes to assure that metal pipe is properly coated and sized according to plans. b. Reject any defective pipe and assure it is not used on the job. c. Observe pipe-laying operation to assure that pipes are true to line and grade, properly located, and bedding and backfill is compacted according to specifications. Document the depth the type of bedding, trench conditions, and backfilling operations. d. Inspect rip-rap or concrete headwalls for proper installation; ensure that drainage catch basins and manholes are installed properly. e. Inspect drainage ditches within the street right-of-way and drainage easements within the subdivision to assure proper embankment slope and grade according to specifications. f. For enclosed storm drainage systems, inspect to ensure that pipes are true to line and grade. Storm drain sewer pipes on steep slopes, greater than 12 percent, should be checked to see that they are properly anchored. Inspect pipe materials and document pipe manufacturer, class and size. Pipe materials for storm sewers shall be reinforced concrete, asphalt coated corrugated steel or other approved materials. Inspect to ensure that sewers are laid with uniform slope between structures and have straight alignments between structures. g. Inspect storm water detention facilities to assure compliance with approved plans, capacity volumes and city construction standards. 3. Sanitary sewer and water main improvements. The water and sewer department shall inspect the following: a. Pipe material, manufacturer, class, and size for conformance with water and sewerage authority specifications. b. Reject any defective materials to assure that they will not be used on the job. c. Observe pipe laying operation to ensure that all joints are properly made, pipes are true to line and grade, compaction and backfill are done according to specifications. d. Document the depth and type of bedding, trench conditions, compaction, the location of all service stub outs and connections, backfilling and location of all utilities. e. Perform and document all final acceptance testing. Section 6.04. - Developer's responsibilities. A. Generally. The subdivider shall be responsible for maintaining documentation of all construction activity. It is recommended that the subdivider retain a professional engineer to supervise, document, and inspect all construction of the subdivision. B. Construction materials records. The subdivider shall maintain all records of all construction materials and quantities used to construct the roads for the subdivision. Asphalt tickets and other material records shall be made available to the city engineer when requested. CHAPTER 7. - LEGAL STATUS
Section 7.01. - Conflict with other laws. When the provisions of this chapter are in conflict with any other law or ordinances, the most restrictive standards shall apply. Section 7.02. - Severability. Should any section or provision of this ordinance be declared by a court of law to be unconstitutional or invalid, such declaration shall not effect the validity of this ordinance other than the specific part that is declared unconstitutional or invalid. Section 7.03. - Appeal provisions. For purposes of this ordinance, any final decision on the interpretation or enforcement hereof shall be placed in writing by the city manager and served upon the developer. If the developer is not also the owner of the property, a copy also [shall] be served on the property owner. Service shall be deemed effective if mailed to the developer/owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the address shown in the application for plan approvals/permits. Any appeal from a decision made by the city manager shall be presented in writing to the city clerk within 30 days of receipt of final action by the city manager. The [city] clerk shall immediately forward a copy of the appeal to the mayor and council. An appeal shall be scheduled at the next regular meeting of the city council if practical, but no later than 21 days from the date of the appeal. Decision of mayor and council shall be final action by the city, subject to review upon writ of certiorari in the superior court. CHAPTER 8. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
Section 8.01. - Administration. The city manager shall administer the process for subdivision plat approval. The manager shall: 1. Receive and review all subdivision plats for conformity with the provisions of this ordinance and the zoning ordinance. 2. Modify or reject any plats that fail to conform to the zoning and subdivision ordinances and make recommendations for improving the layout and design of subdivisions. Section 8.02. - Enforcement. The city manager may authorize enforcement action if the subdivider, or any contractor or subcontractor employed by the subdivider, fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or the Manchester Soil Erosion and Sedimentation Control Ordinance. Section 8.03. - Penalties for violation. Violations of the provisions of this chapter or failure to comply with any of its requirements, including violation of conditions and safeguards in connection with grants of variances shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or by imprisonment of not more than six months and in addition the violator may be required to pay any court costs which lawfully may be imposed. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue. Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. Nothing herein shall prevent the City of Manchester from taking other legal action as determined necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. Section 8.04. - Variances. The city council may authorize a variance after notice and a public hearing where it can be shown that the application of any regulation of this ordinance would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, or where, because of topographical or other conditions unique to the property would create practical difficulty in its development. Notice of the hearing shall be published in the legal organ of Meriwether County at least 15 days prior thereto stating the date, time and location of the hearing, the applicant's name, the location of the development and the nature of the variance sought.
